PT J
AN ZOOR14810072336
DT Article
TI Aphanius arakensis, a new species of tooth-carp (Actinopterygii,
   Cyprinodontidae) from the endorheic Namak Lake basin in Iran.
AU Teimori, Azad (a.teimori@lrz.uni-muenchen.de) 
   Esmaeili, Hamid Reza
   Gholami, Zeinab
   Zarei, Neda
   Reichenbacher, Bettina
SO ZooKeys
VL 215
PS 55-76
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/215/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4954&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species of tooth-carp, Aphanius arakensis sp. n., is described
   from the Namak Lake basin in Iran. he new species is distinguished by
   the congeners distributed in Iran by the following combination of
   characters: 10[long dash]12 anal in rays, 28[long dash]32 lateral line
   scales, 10[long dash]13 caudal peduncle scales, 8[long dash]10 gill
   rakers, 12[long dash]19, commonly 15[long dash]16, clearly deined lank
   bars in males, a more prominent pigmentation along the lank added by
   relatively big blotches in the middle and posterior lank segments in
   females, a short but high antirostrum of the otolith that has a wide
   excisura, and a ventral rim with some small, drop-like processes, and 19
   molecular apomorphies (17 transitions, two transversions) in the
   cytochrome b gene. It was suggested based on the phylogenetic analysis
   that the new species is sister to A. sophiae from the Kor River and that
   A. farsicus from the Maharlu Lake basin is sister to A. arakensis plus
   A. sophiae. A noticeable feature of the Aphanius diversity in Iran is
   the conservatism of the external morphology as well as morphometric and
   meristic characters, while distinctive diferences are present in genetic
   characters, otolith morphology, and male color pattern. Transformation
   of the latter was probably driven by sexual selection.
C1 Teimori, Azad; Department of Earth- and Environmental Sciences,
   Palaeontology & Geobiology & GeoBio-CenterLMU,
   Ludwig-Maximilians-University, Richard-Wagner-Strasse 10, D-80333
   Munich, Germany, Germany.
EM a.teimori@lrz.uni-muenchen.de
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Genetics
   &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Biometrics; Biochemistry; Genetics;
   Evolution; Variation; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Aphanius [Biometrics / Morphometric variation / endemic species]
   [Nucleic acids / mtDNA sequences variation / ] [Molecular genetics /  /
   ] [Evolution /  / ] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Biochemical variation /  / ]
   [Morphological variation /  / ] [Iran /  / distribution]. 
   Aphanius arakensis [Iran /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Cyprinodontiformes, Cyprinodontidae
OR Aphanius (Cyprinodontidae). 
   Aphanius arakensis (Cyprinodontidae): [Sp nov, Iran, P. 62]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14810072336
OA DOAJ Gold, Green Published
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI A charismatic new species of green lacewing discovered in Malaysia
   (Neuroptera, Chrysopidae): the confluence of citizen scientist, online
   image database and cybertaxonomy.
AU Winterton, Shaun L. (wintertonshaun@gmail.com) 
   Guek, Hock Ping
   Brooks, Stephen J.
SO ZooKeys
VL 214
PS 1-11
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/214/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4927&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB An unusual new species of green lacewing (Neuroptera: Chrysopidae:
   Semachrysa jade sp. n.) is described from Selangor (Malaysia) as a joint
   discovery by citizen scientist and professional taxonomists. The
   incidental nature of this discovery is underscored by the fact that the
   species was initially photographed and then released, with images
   subsequently posted to an online image database. It was not until the
   images in the database were randomly examined by the professional
   taxonomists that it was determined that the species was in fact new. A
   subsequent specimen was collected at the same locality and is described
   herein along with another specimen identified from nearby Sabah.
C1 Winterton, Shaun L.; California State Collection of Arthropods,
   California Department of Food & Agriculture, Sacramento, California,
   USA, USA.
EM wintertonshaun@gmail.com
RI Winterton, Shaun L/C-3804-2009
SC Zoology; Computer Science
SN 1313-2970

   Information handling; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Semachrysa [Techniques / Amateur-professional taxonomic collaboration /
   new species identification report] [Use of computers / Online image
   databases & cybertaxonomy / ] [Malaysia / Sabah & Selangor / ]. 
   Semachrysa jade [Malaysia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Neuroptera

TI An aberrant species of Nipponocercyon from Sichuan, China (Coleoptera,
   Hydrophilidae, Sphaeridiinae).
AU Fikacek, Martin (mfkacek@gmail.com) 
   Ryndevich, Sergey
   Jia, Fenglong
SO ZooKeys
VL 214
PS 13-27
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/214/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4930&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A detailed examination of specimens of Cryptopleurum sichuanicum
   Ryndevich, 2005 from high altitudes of Sichuan Province, China, revealed
   that the species belongs in the genus Nipponocercyon Sato, 1963
   previously endemic to Japan. The species is here transferred in
   Nipponocercyon, and N. sichuanicus (Ryndevich, 2005), comb. n. is
   redescribed and compared with N. shibatai Sato, 1963. The male genitalia
   of N. sichuanicus is described for the first time. An adapted diagnosis
   of Nipponocercyon is provided, and reasons for the inclusion of N.
   sichuanicus into Nipponocercyon and the general distribution of the
   genus are discussed.
C1 Fikacek, Martin; Department of Entomology, National Museum, Kunratice 1,
   CZ-148 00 Praha 4, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM mfkacek@gmail.com

   Eurasia; Asia; China

   systematics] [Sichuan /  / ]. 
   Nipponocercyon sichuanicus [Sichuan /  / Distribution; new record;
   systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Hydrophiloidea,
   Hydrophilidae

   17; New record].

   Staphylinini from New Guinea.
AU Solodovnikov, Alexey (asolodovnikov@snm.ku.dk) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 213
PS 51-62
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/213/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4911&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The Staphylinini rove beetle genus Euryporus Erichson from the subtribe
   Quediina is restricted to include only three species from the Western
   Palearctic region: E. picipes (Paykull, 1800), E. aeneiventris (Lucas,
   1846), and E. princeps Wollaston, 1864. Euryporus argentatus Fauvel,
   1881, E. warisensis Last, 1987 and E. multicavus Last, 1980, which do
   not even belong to the subtribe Quediina, are excluded from the genus.
   Of these, two were transferred to diferent genera: Tympanophorus
   argentatus (Fauvel, 1881), comb. nov., from Sumatra; and Hesperus
   warisensis (Last, 1987), comb. nov., from New Guinea. "Euryporus"
   multicavus could not be placed to any of the described genera of
   Staphylinini and is left as incertae sedis pending a broader study of
   the relevant fauna of this tribe in New Guinea and adjacent regions. The
   taxonomic history of Euryporus is reviewed, and an updated diagnosis of
   this genus is provided
C1 Solodovnikov, Alexey; Zoological Museum, Natural History Museum of
   Denmark, Universitetsparken 15, Copenhagen 2100, Denmark, Denmark.
EM asolodovnikov@snm.ku.dk

   Staphylinidae

   diagnosis, P. 53].

DT Article
TI A revision of the genus Mecistostethus Marseul (Histeridae, Histerinae,
   Exosternini).
AU Caterino, Michael S. (mcaterino@sbnature2.org) 
   Tishechkin, Alexey K.
   Degallier, Nicolas
SO ZooKeys
VL 213
PS 63-78
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/213/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4914&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We revise the genus Mecistostethus Marseul, sinking the monotypic genus
   Tarsilister Bruch as a junior synonym. Mecistostethus contains six valid
   species: M. pilifer Marseul, M. loretoensis (Bruch), comb. n., M.
   seagorum sp. n., M. carltoni sp. n., M. marseuli sp. n., and M.
   lechtmanni sp. n. The few existing records show the genus to be
   widespread in tropical and subtropical South America, from northern
   Argentina to western Amazonian Ecuador and French Guiana. Only a single
   host record associates one species with the ant Pachycondyla striata
   Smith (Formicidae: Ponerinae), but it is possible that related ants host
   all the species.
C1 Caterino, Michael S.; Department of Invertebrate Zoology, Santa Barbara
   Museum of Natural History, 2559 Puesta del Sol, Santa Barbara, CA 93105,
   USA, USA.
EM mcaterino@sbnature2.org

   species].

   Mecistostethus flechtmanni (Histeridae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 76]. 
   Mecistostethus loretoensis - (Bruch 1932) (Histeridae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Tarsilister, p. 69]. 
   Mecistostethus marseuli (Histeridae): [Sp nov, French Guiana, P. 74]. 
   Mecistostethus pilifer - Marseul 1870 (Histeridae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 71].

DT Article
TI Studies of the genus Enchodelus Thorne, 1939 (Nematoda, Nordiidae) from
   Arctic Polar deserts. I. Species with long odontostyle: E. makarovae sp.
   n. and E. groenlandicus (Ditlevsen, 1927) Thorne, 1939, with an
   identification key to the species of the E. macrodorus group.
AU Elshishka, Milka
   Lazarova, Stela
   Peneva, Vlada K.
SO ZooKeys
VL 212
PS 1-23
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/212/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4880&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Two nematode species of the genus Enchodelus horne, 1939, one new and
   one known from Arctic polar deserts were studied. Enchodelus makarovae
   sp. n. is an amphimictic species, characterised by females with body
   length of 1.57-2.00 mm, lip region 15-17.5 [mu]m wide, amphid duplex,
   odontostyle 38-43 [mu]m long or 2.3-2.8 times lip region diam.
   Odontophore with langes, 1.2-1.4 times as long as odontostyle; phar- ynx
   length 320-377 [mu]m, pharyngeal expansion 113-130 [mu]m long or 32-37%
   of total pharynx length; female genital system amphidelphic, uterus
   tripartite, pars refringens vaginae with two trapezoid sclerotisations,
   vulva a transverse slit (V=45-51%); tail bluntly conoid (25-35 [mu]m,
   c=45.8-70.3, c'=0.6-0.9 in females, and 29-33 [mu]m, c=46.4[long
   dash]58.9, c'=0.7-0.8 in males). Males with 65-74 [mu]m long spicules
   and 10-12 spaced ventromedian supplements. Additional information for
   Enchodelus groenlandicus is provided, this being a new geographic record
   for the Putorana Plateau, Russian Arctic.

OI Lazarova, Stela/0000-0002-6386-5074

   systematics].

TI A new ant species of the genus Tapinoma (Hymenoptera, Formicidae) from
   Saudi Arabia with a key to the Arabian species.
AU Sharaf, Mostafa R. (antsharaf@yahoo.com) 
   Aldawood, Abdulrahman S.
   ElHawagry, Magdi S.
SO ZooKeys
VL 212
PS 35-43
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/212/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4886&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Tapinoma wilsoni sp. n. is described and illustrated from Saudi Arabia
   based on the worker caste collected from Al Baha, Saudi Arabia. It
   closely resembles Tapinoma lugubre Santschi 1917, from Zimbabwe in body
   measurements but can be distinguished from the latter species by the
   yellowish brown color; the yellowish pubescence, the two pairs of hairs
   present on the anterior part of the head; and the distinctly concave
   anterior clypeal margin. Biological and ecological notes of the new
   species are presented. An identification key to the workers of the
   Arabian species of the genus Tapinoma is given.
C1 Sharaf, Mostafa R.; Plant Protection Department, College of Food and
   Agriculture Sciences, King Saud University, Riyadh 11451, PO Box 2460,
   Saudi Arabia, Saudi Arabia.

DT Article
TI Cucujus tulliae sp. n. - an endemic Mediterranean saproxylic beetle from
   genus Cucujus Fabricius, 1775 (Coleoptera, Cucujidae), and keys for
   identification of adults and larvae native to Europe.
AU Bonacci, Teresa (t.bonacci@unical.it) 
   Mazzei, Antonio
   Horak, Jakub
   Brandmayr, Pietro
SO ZooKeys
VL 212
PS 63-79
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/212/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4892&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Cucujus tulliae sp. n. is described as a new member of genus Cucujus
   Fabricius, 1775 (Coleoptera, Cucujidae), which enumerates at present
   eleven species distributed in Eurasia and northern America. his
   saproxylic beetle is the first Cucujus species known only from
   Mediterranean and it is probably endemic to Calabria (Italy). The
   species was found especially in old-growth mountain forests of high
   conservation value (i.e. national parks) dominated by Calabrian pine
   (Pinus laricio calabrica). We hypothesize that C. tulliae sp. n.
   probably evolved from isolated populations of C. haematodes Erichson,
   1845. The species is thus relictual and of high conservation value,
   corresponding at least to endangered (EN) category with respect to
   recent IUCN criterion. C. tulliae sp. n. is here compared with two
   species native to Europe - C. haematodes and C. cinnaberinus (Scopoli,
   1763) and with the Caucasian C. haematodes caucasicus Motschulsky, 1845,
   which is conirmed as a valid subspecies. he male genitalia of this
   Caucasian form have been examined and illustrated for the first time. A
   comprehensive key to adults and larvae of European species is provided.
C1 Bonacci, Teresa; Dipartimento di Ecologia, Universita della Calabria,
   via P. Pucci, cubo 4b, 87036 Rende (CS), Italy, Italy.
EM t.bonacci@unical.it
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Taxonomy; Status; Key;
   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Cucujus [Eurasia /  / Systematics] [Europe /  / Key to species]. 
   Cucujus tulliae [Italy /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Cucujoidea,
   Cucujidae
OR Cucujus - Fabricius 1775 (Cucujidae): [Key to species, Europe, Adults p.
   73, larvae, p. 74]. 
   Cucujus caucasicus - Motschulsky 1845 (Cucujidae): [First time figured,
   Male genitalia, p. 69; Downgraded to, Cucujus haematodes caucasicus, p.
   71]. 
   Cucujus haematodes caucasicus - Motschulsky 1845 (Cucujidae):
   [Downgraded from, Cucujus caucasicus, p. 71]. 
   Cucujus tulliae (Cucujidae): [Sp nov, Italy, P. 66].

PT J
AN ZOOR14809065883
DT Article
TI A world checklist of Onychophora (velvet worms), with notes on
   nomenclature and status of names.
AU de Sena Oliveira, Ivo (ivo.de_sena_oliveira@uni-leipzig.de) 
   Morley St. J. Read, V.
   Mayer, Georg
SO ZooKeys
VL 211
PS 1-70
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/211/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4877&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Currently, the number of valid species of Onychophora is uncertain. To
   facilitate taxonomic work on this understudied animal group, we present
   an updated checklist for the two extant onychophoran subgroups,
   Peripatidae and Peripatopsidae, along with an assessment of the status
   of each species. According to our study, 82 species of Peripatidae and
   115 species of Peripatopsidae have been described thus far. However,
   among these 197 species, 20 are nomina dubia due to major taxonomic
   inconsistencies. Apart from nomina dubia, many of the valid species also
   require revision, in particular representatives of Paraperipatus within
   the Peripatopsidae, and nearly all species of Peripatidae. In addition
   to extant representatives, the record of unambiguous fossils includes
   three species with uncertain relationship to the extant taxa. For all
   species, we provide a list of synonyms, information on types and type
   localities, as well as remarks on taxonomic and nomenclatural problems
   and misspellings. According to recent evidence of high endemism and
   cryptic speciation among the Peripatidae and Peripatopsidae, previous
   synonyms are revised. Putative mutations, subspecies and variations are
   either raised to the species status or synonymised with corresponding
   taxa. In our revised checklist, we follow the rules and recommendations
   of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature to clarify previous
   inconsistencies.
C1 de Sena Oliveira, Ivo; Animal Evolution and Development, Institute of
   Biology, University of Leipzig, Talstrasse 33, D-04103, Leipzig,
   Germany, Germany.
EM ivo.de_sena_oliveira@uni-leipzig.de
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type species; Synonymy; Available name;
   Unavailable name; Taxonomy; Status; Documentation; Publications

DT Article
TI A review of the genus Raveniola (Araneae, Nemesiidae) in China, with
   notes on allied genera and description of four new species from Yunnan.
AU Zonstein, Sergei (znn@post.tau.ac.il) 
   Marusik, Yuri M.
SO ZooKeys
VL 211
PS 71-99
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/211/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4871&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB he Chinese representatives of Raveniola Zonstein, 1987 are currently
   recognized to comprise seven species. Four new species - R. montana sp.
   n. ([male][female]), R. shangrila sp. n. ([male]), R. songi sp. n.
   ([male]) and R. yunnanensis sp. n. ([male]) - are described from the
   highlands of Yunnan Province, China. According to some characters (shape
   of the palpus, palpal tibia and tibia I in males) they can be placed
   together with R. hebeinica Zhu, Zhang&Zhang, 1999 and with R. guangxi
   (Raven&Schwendinger, 1995), comb. n., transferred here from Sinopesa
   Raven&Schwendinger, 1995. he current generic position of R. xizangensis
   (Hu&Li, 1987) is confirmed. Other Chinese nemesiids referred previously
   to Raveniola are transferred to Sinopesa: S. chinensis (Kulczynski,
   1901), comb. n., S. sinensis (Zhu&Mao, 1983), comb. n. and S.
   chengbuensis (Xu&Yun, 2002), comb. n. he relationships between these
   Asian genera and their relations to Afrotropical nemesiids are
   discussed.

DT Article
TI Notes about morphological features of the Western Hemisphere subtribe
   Ardistomina, and revision of genus Semiardistomis Kult (Coleoptera,
   Carabidae, Scaritinae, Clivinini).
AU Valdes, Pavel (azapata@infomed.sld.cu) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 210
PS 19-67
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/210/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/J_FILES/1/articles/3042/3042-G-3-layout.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Comparisons of structural features (principally mouthparts,
   elytral-abdominal locking mechanism, and female genitalia) of the
   ardistomine genera (Aspidoglossa Putzeys, Ardistomis Putzeys, and
   Semiardistomis Kult) with those features of members of the subtribe
   Clivinina (Clivina Latreille, Oxydrepanus Putzeys, Schizogenius Putzeys,
   Ancus Putzeys, Nyctosyles Putzeys, and Obadius Burmeister) confirm the
   taxonomic validity of the subtribe Ardistomina. Based on morphological
   features, the ardistomine genera are postulated to be related as
   follows: (Aspidoglossa (Ardistomis + Semiardistomis)). Knowledge of this
   subtribe is further extended by taxonomic treatment of the genus
   Semiardistomis Kult. Of the 30 valid names of Semiardistomis previously
   recognized, four were proposed as variety names, and are listed as
   junior synonyms: Ardistomis labialis picipes Bates, 1881, A. l. nanus
   Bates, 1881, and A. l. dilatatus Bates, 1881; and A. pallipes caerulea
   Putzeys, 1846. Eight names, treated as specific epithets, are junior
   synonyms, as follows: Ardistomis (Semiardistomis) balthasari Kult, 1950
   = Semiardistomis glabratus (Putzeys, 1866); A. (S.) emdeni Kult, 1950 =
   S. deletus (Putzeys, 1846); A. aenea Putzeys, 1866, A. (S.) brittoni
   Kult, 1950, and A. (S.) marani Kult, 1950 = S. flavipes (Dejean, 1831);
   A. tuspanensis Putzeys, 1846 = S. labialis (Chaudoir, 1837); A. (S.)
   vlastae Kult, 1950 = S. subglabra (van Emden, 1949); and A. striga
   Putzeys, 1866 = S. pallipes (Dejean, 1831). Two new species described
   are S. exspectatus sp. n. (type locality PERU, Madre de Dios, Rio Manu,
   11[degree]56[minute]47[second]S, 071[degree]17[minute]00[second]W), and
   S. major sp. n. (type locality PERU, Loreto, Rio Samiria,
   05[degree]12[minute]S, 75[degree]20[minute]W). The 20 species of
   Semiardistomis are arranged in two species-groups here proposed: the
   puncticollis group, including 12 species; and labialis group, including
   eight species. The species recognized are keyed, described or
   redescribed, and notes are provided about their Geographical
   distribution, habitat and activity. Distribution maps show known
   geographical ranges, from which are inferred patterns of speciation from
   a center of radiation in northern South America of both lineages.
C1 Valdes, Pavel; Gertrudis 365 apto 5 el D&apos;Strampes y Goicuria, Cp
   10500, Habana, Cuba, Cuba.
EM azapata@infomed.sld.cu
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Diagnosis; Synonymy;
   Taxonomy; Key; Documentation; Publications; Land zones; Neotropical
   region; Central America; West Indies; South America

   Semiardistomis exspectatus [Trinidad and Tobago /  / New species]
   [Ecuador /  / ] [Peru /  / ]. 
   Semiardistomis major [Peru /  / New species].

   brittoni (Kult 1950), p. 53; Syn nov, Semiardistomis marani (Kult 1950),

   Semiardistomis glabratus - (Putzeys 1866) (Carabidae): [Syn nov,
   Semiardistomis balthasari (Kult 1950), p. 39]. 
   Semiardistomis labialis - (Chaudoir 1837) (Carabidae): [Syn nov,
   Semiardistomis tuspanensis (Putzeys 1846), p. 54].

DT Article
TI A new genus of oak gallwasps, Zapatella Pujade-Villar & Melika, gen. n.,
   with a description of two new species from the Neotropics (Hymenoptera,
   Cynipidae, Cynipini).
AU Pujade-Villar, Juli
   Hanson, Paul
   Medina, Claudia A.
   Torres, Miguel
   Melika, George (melikageorge@gmail.com) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 210
PS 75-104
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/210/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/J_FILES/1/articles/3014/3014-G-3-layout.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new genus of cynipid oak gallwasp, Zapatella Pujade-Villar&Melika,
   gen. n. (Hymenoptera: Cynipidae: Cynipini), with two new species,
   Zapatella grahami Pujade-Villar&Melika, sp. n. and Z. nievesaldreyi
   Melika&Pujade-Villar, sp. n., is described from the Neotropics.
   Zapatella grahami, known only from the sexual generation, induces galls
   in acorns of Quercus costaricensis and is currently known only from
   Costa Rica. Zapatella nievesaldreyi, known only from the asexual
   generation, induces inconspicuous galls in twigs of Q. humboldtii, and
   is known only from Colombia. Diagnostic characters for both new species
   are given in detail. Five Nearctic species are transferred from
   Callirhytis to Zapatella: Z. cryptica (Weld), comb. n., Z. herberti
   (Weld), comb. n., Z. oblata (Weld), comb. n., Z. quercusmedullae
   (Ashmead), comb. n., Z. quercusphellos (Osten Sacken), comb. n. (= Z.
   quercussimilis (Bassett), syn. n.). A key based on adults for the
   species belonging to Zapatella is also given. Generic limits and
   morphological characteristics of Zapatella and closely related genera
   are discussed.
C1 Melika, George; Pest Diagnostic Laboratory, Plant Protection & Soil
   Conservation Directorate of County Vas, Ambrozy setany 2, Tanakajd 9762,
   Hungary, Hungary.
EM melikageorge@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Key; Parasites diseases and disorders; Hosts; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; Central America; South America

   species] [Costa Rica /  / New species from plant host]. 
   Zapatella nievesaldreyi [Plant hosts / Quercus humboldtii / New parasite
   species] [Colombia /  / New species from plant host].

   Cynipoidea, Cynipidae

DT Article
TI Mariapanteles (Hymenoptera, Braconidae), a new genus of Neotropical
   microgastrine parasitoid wasp discovered through biodiversity inventory.
AU Whitfield, James B. (jwhitie@life.illinois.edu) 
   Fernandez-Triana, Jose L.
   Janzen, Daniel H.
   Hallwachs, Winnie
   Smith, M. Alex
   Cardinal, Sophie
SO ZooKeys
VL 208
PS 61-80
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/208/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4774&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 1
U2 1
AB A new genus of microgastrine parasitoid wasps, Mariapanteles
   Whitield&Fernandez-Triana, gen. n., is described from rain forests of
   the Neotropics. he new genus is related to the common and speciose genus
   Pseudapanteles, but can be distinguished from the latter by having a
   complete transverse carina on the pro- podeum which forks around the
   spiracles. A molecular analysis based on data from COI from specimens of
   the proposed new genus plus possibly related genera conirms its generic
   distinctness. A key to two known species, M. felipei Whitield, sp. n.
   (Costa Rica) and M. dapkeyae Fernandez-Triana, sp. n. (Brazil) is
   provided. Evidence from collections suggests that there are other
   undescribed Neotropical congenerics. Specimens of Mariapanteles were
   likely confused in the past with the genus Beyarslania (referred to as
   Xenogaster until recently) but present information suggests that
   Beyarslania is restricted to the Afrotropical region while the
   Neotropical species clearly belong to a diferent genus, which we propose
   as new.
C1 Whitfield, James B.; Department of Entomology, 320 Morrill Hall, 5050 S.
   Goodwin Ave., University of Illinois, Urbana, IL 61801, USA, USA.
EM jwhitie@life.illinois.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; Central America; South America
DE Mariapanteles dapkeyae [Brazil /  / New species]. 
   Mariapanteles felipei [Costa Rica /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia,
   Ichneumonoidea, Braconidae
OR Mariapanteles - Whitfield & Fernandez-Triana 2012 (Braconidae): [Gen
   nov, Of subfamily Microgastrinae, Type species Mariapanteles felipei
   Whitfield 2012, p. 66; Key to species, P. 68]. 
   Mariapanteles dapkeyae - Fernandez-Triana 2012 (Braconidae): [Sp nov,
   Brazil, Host unknown, p. 72]. 
   Mariapanteles felipei - Whitfield 2012 (Braconidae): [Sp nov, Costa
   Rica, Host unknown, p. 68].

DT Article
TI A new genus and species of Metopiinae (Hymenoptera, Ichneumonidae) from
   Mexico.
AU Khalaim, Andrey I. (ptera@mail.ru) 
   Ruiz-Cancino, Enrique
   Coronado-Blanco, Juana M.
SO ZooKeys
VL 207
PS 1-10
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/207/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4744&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A new genus of Metopiinae, Ojuelos Khalaim, gen. n., with a single
   species, Ojuelos juachicus Khalaim&Ruiz-Cancino, sp. n., is described
   from Jalisco Province in central Mexico. Ojuelos belongs to the group of
   three genera (Cubus Townes&Townes, Colpotrochia Holmgren and Triclistus
   Forster) having a high lamella separating the antennal sockets and
   reaching the median ocellus (this lamella possesses a dorsal groove in
   it, just below the median ocellus), but difers from these genera
   primarily by 1) face and clypeus not convex in lateral view, 2) face
   separated from clypeus by a shallow transverse impression, 3) mandible
   with lower tooth very strongly reduced, 4) lagellomeres of antenna
   strongly transverse, and 5) dorsal carinae of propodeum reduced. A
   portion of the key to the genera of Metopiinae is provided to
   distinguish the new genus.
C1 Khalaim, Andrey I.; Division de Estudios de Postgrado e Investigacion,
   Facultad de Ingenieira y Ciencias, Universidad Autonoma de Tamaulipas,
   Cd. Victoria 87149, Mexico, Mexico.
EM ptera@mail.ru

OI Ruiz-Cancino, Enrique/0000-0003-4305-6568; Coronado-Blanco, Juana
   Maria/0000-0002-8387-7734; Khalaim, Andrey I./0000-0003-1802-2649

TI Taxonomic studies on genus Tetramorium Mayr (Hymenoptera, Formicidae)
   with report of two new species and three new records including a tramp
   species from India with a revised key.
AU Bharti, Himender (himenderbharti@gmail.com) 
   Kumar, Rakesh
SO ZooKeys
VL 207
PS 11-35
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/207/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4747&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Two new species of Tetramorium Mayr, namely T. shivalikense sp. n. and
   T. triangulatum sp. n. are described. Tetramorium triangulatum sp. n.
   belongs to the inglebyi-species group and is described based on worker,
   queen and male caste, while T. shivalikense sp. n. belongs to the
   ciliatum-species group and is described based on worker caste only. hree
   species viz., T. caldarium (Roger), T. tonganum Mayr and T. urbanii
   Bolton represent irst records from India. The male caste is described
   for the irst time in the case of T. tonganum. Among these, T. caldarium
   is a tramp species which extends its limit to India as well. A revised
   key to the Indian ants of this genus is also provided herewith.

AN ZOOR14809064634
DT Article
TI A new species of Orobdella (Hirundinida, Arhynchobdellida, Orobdellidae)
   from Taipei, Taiwan.
AU Nakano, Takafumi (nakano@zoo.zool.kyoto-u.ac.jp) 
   Lai, Yi-Te
SO ZooKeys
VL 207
PS 49-63
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/207/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4753&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new quadrannulate species of Orobdella, Orobdella ketagalan sp. n.,
   from Taipei, Taiwan, is described. This is the first record of Orobdella
   and the family Orobdellidae from Taiwan. his new species possesses
   small, paired sperm duct bulbs in the male reproductive system. In
   addition to these bulbs, the following combination of characters
   distinguishes this new species from other quadrannulate species: somite
   IV uniannulate, male gonopore at XI b6, female gonopore at XIII a1, 1/2
   + 4 + 1/2 between gonopores, simple tubular gastroporal duct, lacking
   epididymides, and undeveloped atrial cornua. Phylogenetic analyses using
   nuclear 18S rDNA and histone H3 as well as mitochondrial COI, 12S rDNA,
   tRNAVal, and 16S rDNA markers showed that O. ketagalan is related to the
   two Ryukyu Archipelago species Orobdella dolichopharynx Nakano, 2011 and
   Orobdella shimadae Nakano, 2011.
C1 Nakano, Takafumi; Department of Zoology, Graduate School of Science,
   Kyoto University, Kyoto 606-8502, Japan, Japan.
EM nakano@zoo.zool.kyoto-u.ac.jp
SC Genetics &Heredity; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Genetics; Evolution;
   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Orobdella [Molecular genetics / 18S rDNA &amp; mtDNA sequence phylogeny
   / Taxonomic implications] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Asia / East Asia / ]
   [Taiwan / Taipei City / New record]. 
   Orobdella ketagalan [Taiwan /  / New species]. 
   Orobdellidae [Taiwan / Taipei City / New record]. 
TN Annelids; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Annelida, Hirudinea
OR Orobdella - Oka 1895 (Hirudinea): [Diagnostic characters of subordinate
   taxa, P. 57; New record]. 
   Orobdella ketagalan (Hirudinea): [Sp nov, Taiwan, P. 53]. 
   Orobdellidae (Hirudinea): [New record].

AB The species of the water scavenger beetle genus Berosus Leach occurring
   in Venezuela are reviewed. Thirty- six species are recorded, including
   ifteen new species, fourteen of which are described here as new: B.
   aragua sp. n., B. asymmetricus sp. n., B. capanaparo sp. n., B.
   castaneus sp. n., B. corozo sp. n., B. ebeninus sp. n., B. garciai sp.
   n., B. humeralis sp. n., B. jolyi sp. n., B. llanensis sp. n., B.
   megaphallus sp. n., B. or- naticollis sp. n., B. repertus sp. n., and B.
   tramidrum sp. n. he ifteenth new species, known from a single female, is
   left undescribed pending the collection of males. Twelve species are
   recorded from Venezuela for the irst time: B. ambogynus Mouchamps, B.
   consobrinus Knisch, B. elegans Knisch, B. geayi d'Orchymont, B. ghanicus

AB North American members in the genus Radiolucina are reviewed. A
   lectotype for the type species, Radiolucina amianta, is designated and
   descriptions and illustrations are provided. A description of a new

   compared among members of the genus.

AB The genus Sinotrisus Yin&Li, comprising four species, is redeined and
   revised. Members of Sinotrisus are often found with ants of the
   subfamily Formicinae, or in humid forest habitats. he type species and
   three new species are (re-)described and illustrated: S. kishimotoi
   Yin&Nomura, sp. n. (China: Sichuan), S. nomurai Yin, Li&Zhao (type
   species) (China: Zhejing), S. sinensis Yin&Nomura, sp. n. (China:
   Sichuan) and S. vietnamensis Yin&Nomura, sp. n. (Vietnam: Lai Chau). A
   key is included as an aid to distinguishing these species.

TI Review of the Eospilarctia yuennanica group (Lepidoptera, Erebidae,
   Arctiinae) from the Indo-Himalayan region, with description of two new
   species and one subspecies.
AU Saldaitis, Aidas
   Ivinskis, Povilas (ivinskis@ekoi.lt) 
   Witt, Thomas
   Pekarsky, Oleg
SO ZooKeys
VL 204
PS 53-70
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/204/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4698&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Two new Eospilarctia species and one new subspecies from China, Myanmar
   and Vietnam, respectively, are described. Supericially the new species
   Eospilarctia maciai sp. n., Eospilarctia naumanni sp. n. and
   Eospilarctia yuennanica fansipana ssp. n. resemble related congeners but
   they can be distinguished by the diferences in wing pattern, genitalia
   and distribution provided. Eospilarctia yuennanica guangdonga Dubatolov,
   Kishida&Wang, 2008 is upgraded to species level. A checklist of the
   genus Eospilarctia and a key to the Eospilarctia yuennanica (Daniel,
   1943) species-group, based on external characters and male genitalia, is
   presented.

PT J
AN ZOOR14808059241
DT Article
TI A new species of Chalicodoma from Saudia Arabia with modified facial
   setae (Hymenoptera, Megachilidae).
AU Alqarni, Abdulaziz S. (alqarni@ksu.edu.sa) 
   Hannan, Mohammed A.
   Gonzalez, Victor H.
   Engel, Michael S.
SO ZooKeys
VL 204
PS 71-83
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/204/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4701&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Some bees and pollen wasps have independently evolved simple, stif,
   erect, apically-curved, curly or hooked facial setae as adaptations to
   collect pollen from nototribic lowers. A distinctive new species of
   Chalicodoma Lepeletier de Saint Fargeau subgenus Pseudomegachile Friese
   from Saudi Arabia with such morphological adaptations, C. riyadhense sp.
   n., is described and figured. The species was captured visiting lowers
   of Blepharis ciliaris (L.) (Acanthaceae). The occurrence of modiied
   facial setae is documented and discussed for the first time in eight
   other species of Pseudomegachile, and a key to the genera and subgenera
   of Megachilini currently confirmed for Saudi Arabia is provided.
C1 Alqarni, Abdulaziz S.; Department of Plant Protection, College of Food
   and Agriculture Sciences, King Saud University, P.O. Box 2460, Riyadh
   11451, Saudi Arabia, Saudi Arabia.
EM alqarni@ksu.edu.sa

TI A new species of Oxelytrum Gistel (Coleoptera, Silphidae) from southern
   Argentina, with a key to the species of the genus.
AU Oliva, Adriana (arg_insect@yahoo.com.ar) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 203
PS 1-14
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/203/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4669&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB A new species of the forensically interesting genus Oxelytrum Gistel
   (Coleoptera, Silphidae), O. selknan, is described from Santa Cruz and
   Tierra del Fuego provinces, Argentina. he new species resembles O.
   biguttatum (Philippi) in outer aspect, but has diferent male genitalia,
   in particular a median lobe longer than the paramera. All the described
   species of Oxelytrum have the median lobe shorter than the paramera. he
   internal sac, as far as it could be reconstructed from dry-pinned
   specimens, also shows diferences between the two species. A key to the
   species of Oxelytrum is given and illustrated.

   Argentina, Argentina.

TI A review of the genus Neopsocopsis (Psocodea, "Psocoptera", Psocidae),
   with one new species from China.
AU Liu, Lu-Xi
   Yoshizawa, Kazunori
   Li, Fa-Sheng
   Liu, Zhi-Qi (zhiqiliu@cau.edu.cn) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 203
PS 27-46
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/203/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4675&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A review of species of the genus Neopsocopsis Badonnel, 1936 is
   presented. Four species are redescribed, viz. N. hirticornis (Reuter,
   1893), N. quinquedentata (Li&Yang, 1988), N. profunda (Li, 1995), and N.
   lavida (Li, 1989), as well as the description of one new species, N.
   convexa sp. n. Seven new synonymies are proposed as follows: Pentablaste
   obconica Li syn. n. and P. clavata Li syn. n. of N. hirticornis, P.
   tetrae- drica Li syn. n. of N. longiptera, Neoblaste schizopetala Li
   syn. n. and Nb. lavae Li syn. n. of N. profunda, Blastopsocidus pini Li
   syn. n. and P. lanceolata Li syn. n. of N. lavida. N. hirticornis
   (Reuter, 1893) is recorded from Japan and China for the irst time, and
   N. longiptera Vishnyakova, 1986 is newly recorded from China.
   Illustrated keys to adult males and females are presented.
C1 Liu, Zhi-Qi; Department of Entomology, China Agricultural University,
   Beijing, 100193, China, China.
EM zhiqiliu@cau.edu.cn

   P. 32].

TI Description of Crassolabium persicum sp. n. (Nematoda, Dorylaimida,
   Qudsianematidae), an interesting species from Iran.
AU Jabbari, Habibeh
   Niknam, Gholamreza (g_niknam@tabrizu.ac.ir) 
   Vinciguerra, Maria Teresa
   Moslehi, Shalaleh
   Abolafia, Joaquin
   Pena-Santiago, Reyes
SO ZooKeys
VL 203
PS 55-63
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/203/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4684&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Crassolabium, C. persicum sp. n., collected
   from Arasbaran rangelands of Iran, is described and illustrated. It is
   characterized by its body 1.92[long dash]2.40 mm long, lip region ofset
   by constriction and 17[long dash]19 [mu]m wide, odontostyle 16[long
   dash]19 [mu]m long with aperture occupying less than one[long dash]third
   (27[long dash]30%) its length, neck 428[long dash]690 [mu]m long,
   pharyngeal expansion 369[long dash]390 [mu]m long or occupying 54[long
   dash]56% of total neck length, female genital system amphidelphic,
   uterus bipartite and 162[long dash]218 [mu]m long or 2.3[long dash]3.5
   times as long as body diameter, pars refringens vaginae well developed,
   V = 54[long dash]57.5, vulva longitudinal, prerectum bearing a blind
   sac, tail conical with rounded tip to conoid (25[long dash]36 [mu]m,
   c=60[long dash]69, c'=0.5[long dash]0.9), spicules 68[long dash]72 [mu]m
   long, precloacal pair of supplements far (22[long dash]27 [mu]m) from
   cloacal aperture, and 13[long dash]17 shortly spaced ventromedian
   supplements with hiatus. he new taxon is compared in depth to its
   relatives in Crassolabium as well as other similar species of
   Aporcelaimellus and Amblydorylaimus.
C1 Niknam, Gholamreza; Nematology Lab, Faculty of Agriculture, University
   of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran, Iran.
EM g_niknam@tabrizu.ac.ir

AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/202/

AB he Afrotropical Oberthuerellinae are revised, and new dichotomous and
   multi-entry keys to the spe- cies of Oberthuerella, Tessmannella, and
   Xenocynips are provided. All previously described species in these
   genera are redescribed; descriptions are augmented by color images of
   the holotype for each species. he following 11 species are described as
   new: Oberthuerella cyclopia Buington&van Noort; O. eschara Buf-
   ington&van Noort; O. kibalensis van Noort&Buington; O. pardolatus
   Buington&van Noort; O. sharkeyi Buington&van Noort; O. simba
   Buington&van Noort; Tessmannella copelandi Buington&van Noort; T.
   kiplingi Buington&van Noort; T. roberti Buington&van Noort; Xenocynips
   rhothion Buington&van Noort; and X. ronquisti Buington&van Noort. We
   provide identiication keys to the genera and species occurring in the
   Afrotropical region. Online dichotomous and interactive Lucid keys to
   genera and species are available at

TI Taxonomic overview of Polymixis serpentina (Treitschke, 1825)
   species-group, with the description of a new species (Lepidoptera,
   Noctuidae, Xyleninae).
AU Pekarsky, Oleg (opbp@t-online.hu) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 201
PS 15-26
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/201/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/J_FILES/1/articles/3035/3035-G-3-layout.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The taxa of the Polymixis serpentina (Treitschke, 1825) species-group
   are revised. The external and genital features of all known taxa and a
   new species, P. ivanchiki sp. n. (Lebanon, Israel, Turkey and Iran) are
   described and illustrated. P. serpentina iatnana Hacker, 1996, is
   treated here as a species distinct from P. serpentina (stat. n.). A
   diagnostic comparison of the members of the species-group is provided;
   descriptions of the genitalia of Polymixis serpentina minoica Fibiger,
   1992 and P. iatnana are given for the first time.

TI A review of the alderfly genus Leptosialis Esben- Petersen (Megaloptera,
   Sialidae) with description of a new species from South Africa.
AU Price, Benjamin W.

   de Moor, Ferdy C.
   Villet, Martin H.
SO ZooKeys
VL 201
PS 27-41

PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/201/

LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The monotypic South African alderfly genus Leptosialis Esben-Petersen,
   1920 is reviewed and Leptosialis africana Esben-Petersen, 1920 is
   redescribed. In the process a new species of alderfly Leptosialis
   necopinata sp. n. from the Eastern Cape and KwaZulu-Natal provinces of
   South Africa is recognised and described. Within Sialidae the new
   species most closely resembles L. africana. A key to the two species of
   Leptosialis using both adult and larval characters is provided.

DT Article
TI Four new species of Dolichopoda Bolivar, 1880 from Southern Sporades and
   Western Turkey (Orthoptera, Rhaphidophoridae, Dolichopodainae).
AU Rampini, Mauro (mauro.rampini@uniroma1.it) 
   Di Russo, Claudio
   Taylan, Mehmet Sait
   Gelosa, Arianna
   Cobolli, Marina
SO ZooKeys
VL 201
PS 43-58
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/201/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/J_FILES/1/articles/2609/2609-G-3-layout.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A description of four new species of Dolichopoda Bolivar, 1880
   (Orthoptera, Rhaphidophoridae) from Eastern Aegean region (Southern
   Sporades), including Western Turkey, is reported. This brings to a total
   of 11 the number of Dolichopoda species recorded for caves of the Aegean
   area. Overall, these species show a high degree of morphological
   homogeneity and they are very close to D. paraskevi Boudou-Saltet, 1973
   from Crete and D. naxia Boudou-Saltet, 1972 from Cyclades (Naxos
   Island). The Western Turkish species are morphologically not closely
   related to the other Anatolian species; this suggests an independent
   origin for the taxa occurring in the Southern Taurus and Black Sea
   regions. These new data help to better define the already high level of
   diversity of the Hellenic Dolichopoda and strengthen the hypothesis that
   the central area of dispersal for the genus would correspond to the
   ancient Aegean plate.
C1 Rampini, Mauro; Dipartimento di Biologia e Biotecnologie &quot;C.
   Darwin&quot; (Zoologia), Universita degli Studi di Roma &quot;La
   Sapienza&quot;, Viale dell&apos;Universita 32, 00185 Roma, Italy, Italy.
EM mauro.rampini@uniroma1.it
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe

TI A new species of Caligus (Copepoda, Siphonostomatoida) from the plankton
   of the Caribbean coast of Venezuela with a key to species.
AU Suarez-Morales, Eduardo (esuarez@ecosur.mx) 
   Camisotti, Humberto
   Martin, Alberto
SO ZooKeys
VL 201
PS 59-71
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/201/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/J_FILES/1/articles/3099/3099-G-3-layout.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB During a survey of the zooplankton community of Bahia Amuay, Venezuelan
   Caribbean, specimens of an undescribed species of Caligus Muller were
   collected. It resembles C. xystercus Cressey and C. ocyurus Cressey,
   both known only from the Caribbean Sea. The new species can be
   distinguished from these and other congeners by a combination of
   characters including the armature of legs 1 and 4, but mainly by its
   unique female genital complex. This is the first species of Caligus
   described from Venezuela. The species is described in full and a key to
   the species of the genus recorded in Venezuela is provided.

TI A new marine gobiid species of the genus Clariger Jordan & Snyder
   (Gobiidae, Teleostei) from Taiwan.
AU Jang-Liaw, Nian-Hong
   Gong, You-Hai
   Chen, I-Shiung (iscfish@yahoo.com.tw) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 199
PS 13-21
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/199/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4614&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A new species of Clariger Jordan&Snyder, 1901 was collected from
   northern Taiwan. The genus was previously known only from Japanese
   waters. his discovery is the irst formal and southernmost record of
   these marine gobies from the waters of subtropical Taiwan. The new
   species, Clariger taiwanensis sp. n., is distinguished from its
   congeners by a unique combination of features: (1) in rays: dorsal-in
   rays III, I/8; anal-fin rays modally I/8; and pectoral-fin rays modally
   19 (2+16+1); (2) longitudinal dermal ridge on head with 6 barbels; and
   (3) speciic coloration pattern: head and trunk dark brown with scattered
   pale spots and blotches; cheek, ventral portion of head sometimes pale
   with deep brown spots; pectoral-in base with a dark brown band; and
   caudal in mostly dark brown proximally and with alternating and
   irregular dark brown and pale bands distally. A diagnostic key to all
   nominal species from Japan and Taiwan is provided.
C1 Chen, I-Shiung; Institute of Marine Biology, National Taiwan Ocean
   University, Keelung 20224, Taiwan, Taiwan.
EM iscfish@yahoo.com.tw
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970

   Pacific Ocean

   Distribution; new record; systematics].

PT J
AN ZOOR14807052827
DT Article
TI Taxonomy and species-groups of the subgenus Crematogaster (Orthocrema)
   in the Malagasy region (Hymenoptera, Formicidae).
AU Blaimer, Bonnie B. (bbblaimer@ucdavis.edu) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 199
PS 23-70
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/199/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4617&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The species-level taxonomy of the subgenus Crematogaster (Orthocrema) in
   the Malagasy region is evalu- ated with both morphological data from
   worker and queen ants, and genetic data from three nuclear markers (long
   wavelength rhodopsin, arginine kinase and carbamoylphosphate synthase).
   hese two types of data support the existence of six Orthocrema species:
   Crematogaster madecassa Emery, C. rasoherinae Forel, C. telolafy sp. n.,
   C. razana sp. n., C. volamena sp. n. and C. mpanjono sp. n.. Two new
   synonyms of C. rasoherinae Forel are recognized, C. rasoherinae
   brunneola Emery, syn. n. and C. voeltzkowi Forel, syn. n., as these were
   not supported as distinct taxa by the data. A neotype is designated for
   C. rasoherinae; lectotypes are designated for C. madecassa, C.
   rasoherinae brunneola and C. voeltzkowi. Species descriptions, images,
   distribution maps and identiication keys based on worker and queen ants
   are given for all six species. A diagnosis of the subgenus Orthocrema in
   the Malagasy region is presented for both workers and queens. Within the
   Malagasy Orthocrema, three distinct phylogenetic lineages are suggested
   by molecular and morphological data. Newly deined monophyletic
   species-groups are thus the C. madecassa-group (C. madecassa, C.
   telolafy and C. razana) and the C. volamena-group (C. volamena and C.
   mpanjono); C. rasoherinae represents an isolated lineage in the Malagasy
   region and its closest relatives remain unclear. Other interesting
   biological indings are the presence of an intermediate caste between
   workers and queens in C. rasoherinae and C. madecassa, and unusually
   large workers in C. volamena resembling a major caste.
C1 Blaimer, Bonnie B.; Department of Entomology, University of
   California-Davis, One Shields Ave, Davis, CA 95616, USA, USA.
EM bbblaimer@ucdavis.edu

DT Article
TI A revision of the genus Kaszabister Mazur (Histeridae, Histerinae,
   Exosternini).
AU Degallier, Nicolas
   Mazur, Slawomir
   Tishechkin, Alexey K.
   Caterino, Michael S. (mcaterino@sbnature2.org) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 199
PS 71-89
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/199/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4620&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB We revise the four species of Kaszabister Mazur, 1972, one of which,
   Kaszabister barrigai sp. n., is described as new. The other species in
   the genus are K. rubellus (Erichson, 1834), K. ferrugineus (Kirsch,
   1873) and K. carinatus (Lewis, 1888). The species are principally known
   from the subtropics of South America, with one in Central America.
   Lectotypes are designated for K. rubellus and K. ferrugineus, and a key
   is provided for all the species. Ants of the genus Solenopsis Westwood,
   mainly S. invicta Buren and S. saevissima (Smith), are documented as
   hosts of three of the four species.
C1 Caterino, Michael S.; Department of Invertebrate Zoology, Santa Barbara
   Museum of Natural History, 2559 Puesta del Sol, Santa Barbara,
   California 93105, USA, USA.
EM mcaterino@sbnature2.org
RI Degallier, Nicolas/D-4296-2014

DT Article
TI Serpula and Spiraserpula (Polychaeta, Serpulidae) from the Tropical
   Western Atlantic and Gulf of Guinea.
AU Bastida-Zavala, Rolando (rolando@angel.umar.mx) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 198
PS 1-23
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/198/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4584&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Six species of Serpula and Spiraserpula were identiied, mainly, from the
   material of the expeditions of the Rosenstiel School of Marine and
   Atmospheric Science, University of Miami, including two new species of
   Serpula. Serpula madrigalae sp. n. from the Turks and Caicos has a tube
   with ive longitudinal ridges, four rows of alveoli and a medium-sized
   shallow symmetrical opercular funnel with 17 radii, and an in- ner
   surface with opercular tubercles. Serpula vossae sp. n. from the Western
   Caribbean and Bahamas has a tube with 6[long dash]8 longitudinal ridges,
   and a large, deep symmetrical opercular funnel, with 21[long dash]33
   radii, and a smooth inner surface. Serpula cf. vermicularis, recorded
   from the Gulf of Guinea (tropical eastern Atlantic), is distinguished
   from the nominal species in possessing fewer opercular radii (33[long
   dash]39) and the lack of a proximal rasp in the bayonet chaetae; tubes
   are missing. he distribution range is extended for the three known
   Spiraserpula species found in the collections, S. caribensis, S.
   karpatensis and S. ypsilon.

   Mexico.

TI New systematic assignments in Gonyleptoidea (Arachnida, Opiliones,
   Laniatores).
AU Pinto-da-Rocha, Ricardo (ricrocha@usp.br) 
   Benedetti, Alipio Rezende
   de Vasconcelos, Eduardo Gomes
   Hara, Marcos Ryotaro
SO ZooKeys
VL 198
PS 25-68
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/198/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4587&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB As part of an ongoing revision of the family Gonyleptidae, we have
   identiied many species that are syno- nyms of previously described
   species or misplaced in this family. his article summarizes these
   indings, adding previously unavailable information or correcting
   imprecise observations to justify the presented taxonomic changes. he
   following new familial or subfamilial assignments are proposed:
   Nemastygnus Roewer, 1929 and Taulisa Roewer, 1956 are transferred to
   Agoristenidae, Agoristeninae; Napostygnus Roewer, 1929 to Cra- naidae;
   Ceropachylinus peruvianus Roewer, 1956 and Pirunipygus Roewer, 1936 are
   transferred to Go- nyleptidae, Ampycinae; Gyndesops Roewer, 1943,
   Haversia Roewer, 1913 and Oxapampeus Roewer, 1963 are transferred to
   Gonyleptidae, Pachylinae. he following generic synonymies are proposed
   for the family Gonyleptidae: Acanthogonyleptes Mel- lo-Leitao, 1922 =
   Centroleptes Roewer, 1943; Acrographinotus Roewer, 1929 = Unduavius
   Roewer, 1929; Gonyleptes Kirby, 1819 = Collonychium Bertkau, 1880;
   Mischonyx Bertkau, 1880 = Eugonyleptes Roewer, 1913 and Gonazula Roewer,
   1930; Parampheres Roewer, 1913 = Metapachyloides Roewer, 1917; Pseu-
   dopucrolia Roewer, 1912 = Meteusarcus Roewer, 1913; Haversia Roewer,
   1913 = Hoggellula Roewer, 1930. he following speciic synonymies are
   proposed for the family Gonyleptidae: Acanthogonyleptes singularis
   (Mello-Leitao, 1935) = Centroleptes lavus Roewer, 1943, syn. n.;
   Geraeocormobius sylvarum Holmberg, 1887 = Discocyrtus serrifemur Roewer,
   1943, syn. n.; Gonyleptellus bimaculatus (Sorensen, 1884) = Gonyleptes
   cancellatus Roewer, 1917, syn. n.; Gonyleptes atrus Mello-Leitao, 1923 =
   Weyhia brieni Giltay, 1928, syn. n.; Gonyleptes fragilis Mello-Leitao,
   1923 = Gonyleptes banana Kury, 2003, syn. n.; Gonyleptes horridus Kirby,
   1819 = Collonychium bicuspidatum Bertkau, 1880, syn. n., Gonyleptes
   borgmeyeri Mello-Leitao, 1932, syn. n., Gonyleptes curvicornis
   Mello-Leitao, 1932, syn. n., Metagonyleptes hamatus Roewer, 1913, syn.
   n. and Paragonyleptes simoni Roewer, 1930, syn. n.; Gonyleptes
   pustulatus Sorensen, 1884 = Gonyleptes guttatus Roewer, 1917, syn. n.;
   Haversia defensa (Butler, 1876) = Sadocus vallentini Hogg, 1913, syn.
   n.; Liogonyleptoides minensis (Piza, 1946) = Cur- rala bahiensis Soares,
   1972, syn. n.; Megapachylus grandis Roewer, 1913 = Metapachyloides
   almeidai Soares&Soares, 1946, syn. n.; Mischonyx cuspidatus (Roewer,
   1913) = Gonazula gibbosa Roewer, 1930 syn. n.; Mischonyx scaber (Kirby,
   1819) = Xundarava holacantha Mello-Leitao, 1927, syn. n.; Parampheres
   tibialis Roewer, 1917 = Metapachyloides rugosus Roewer, 1917, syn. n.;
   Parapachyloides uncinatus (Sorensen, 1879) = Goyazella armata
   Mello-Leitao, 1931, syn. n.; Pseudopucrolia mutica (Perty, 1833) =
   Meteusarcus armatus Roewer, 1913, syn. n. he following new combinations
   are proposed: Acrographinotus ornatus (Roewer, 1929), comb. n. (ex
   Unduavius); Gonyleptellus bimaculatus (Sorensen, 1884), comb. n. (ex
   Gonyleptes); Gonyleptes perlatus (Mello-Leitao, 1935), comb. n. (ex
   Moojenia); Mischonyx scaber (Kirby, 1819), comb. n. (ex Gonyleptes); and
   Neopachyloides peruvianus (Roewer, 1956), comb. n. (ex Ceropachylus). he
   following species of Gonyleptidae, Gonyleptinae are revalidated:
   Gonyleptes atrus Mello-Leitao, 1923 and Gonyleptes curvicornis (Roewer,
   1913).
C1 Pinto-da-Rocha, Ricardo; Departamento de Zoologia, Instituto de

   n., are described from Liupanshan Nature Reserve, Ningxia Hui Autonomous

   key to species of Ox- ycera from China. he type specimens are deposited
   in the Institute of Entomology, Guizhou University, Guiyang (GUGC).

TI A new species of Mengenilla (Insecta, Strepsiptera) from Tunisia.
AU Pohl, Hans (hans.pohl@uni-jena.de) 
   Niehuis, Oliver
   Gloyna, Kai
   Misof, Bernhard
   Beutel, Rolf G.
SO ZooKeys
VL 198
PS 79-101
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/198/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4593&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species of Mengenilla Hofeneder, 1910 (Strepsiptera,
   Mengenillidae) from southern Tunisia is described. Mengenilla moldrzyki
   sp. n. can be distinguished from congeners by a slightly emarginated
   posterodorsal margin of the head, compound eyes with a light tan dorsal
   part, mandibles with a narrow distal part, and a v-shaped pronotum. With
   the description of M. moldrzyki sp. n., eleven valid species of
   Mengenilla are currently recognised. Mengenilla moldrzyki sp. n. is the
   third species of the genus with known females and female puparia. First
   instar larvae, endoparasitic larval stages, the male puparium and the
   host are unknown. he new species is also the irst strepsipteran with a
   fully sequenced genome.
C1 Pohl, Hans; Entomology Group, Institut fuer Spezielle Zoologie und
   Evolutionsbiologie, Friedrich-Schiller-Universitaet Jena, Erbertstrasse
   1, 07743 Jena, Germany, Germany.
EM hans.pohl@uni-jena.de
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970

   Palaearctic region; Africa
DE Mengenilla moldrzyki [Tunisia /  / New species].

TI A new golden frog species of the genus Diasporus (Amphibia,
   Eleutherodactylidae) from the Cordillera Central, western Panama.
AU Hertz, Andreas (ahertz@senckenberg.de) 
   Hauenschild, Frank
   Lotzkat, Sebastian
   Koehler, Gunther
SO ZooKeys
VL 196
PS 23-46
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/196/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4553&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB We describe the frog species Diasporus citrinobapheus sp. n. from the
   Cordillera Central of western Pana- ma. he new species difers from all
   other species in its genus in coloration, disk cover and disk pad shape,
   skin texture, advertisement call, and size. It is most similar to D.
   tigrillo, from which it difers in dorsal skin texture, relative tibia
   length, number of vomerine teeth, ventral coloration, dorsal markings,
   and relative tympanum size, and to D. gularis, from which it can be
   distinguished by the lack of membranes between the toes, adult size,
   posterior thigh coloration, and position of the choanae. We provide data
   on morpho- logy, vocalization, and distribution of the new species, as
   well as brief information on its natural history.
C1 Hertz, Andreas; Senckenberg Forschunginstitut und Naturmuseum,
   Senckenberganlage 25, 60325 Frankfurt am, Main, Germany, Germany.
EM ahertz@senckenberg.de

   history]. 
   Diasporus citrinobapheus [Panama /  / New species].

TI Eriophyoid mites from Qinghai Province, northwestern China with
   descriptions of nine new species (Acari, Eriophyoidea).
AU Li, Hao-Sen
   Xue, Xiao-Feng
   Hong, Xiao-Yue (xyhong@njau.edu.cn) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 196
PS 47-107
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/196/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4556&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Eriophyoid mites from Qinghai Province, northwestern China were studied
   herein. Up to now, only six species have been reported from Qinghai
   Province. In ield surveys, 17 eriophyoid mite species were col- lected,
   among which nine species were found new to science. he new species and
   their host plants are listed as follows: Acaphyllisa tuberculumae sp. n.
   on Populus sp. (Salicaceae); Proiectus xiningensis sp. n. on Pinus sp.
   (Pinaceae); Phyllocoptes beishaniensis sp. n. on Spiraea mongolica
   Maxim. (Rosaceae); Tetra pruniana sp. n. on Prunus tomentosa hunb.
   (Rosaceae) Rupr. (Berberidaceae); Tetra pyriana sp. n. on Pyrus
   calleryana Decne. (Rosaceae); Tetra simonia sp. n. on Populus simonii
   Carr. (Salicaceae); Diptacus berberinus sp. n. on Berberis amurensis
   Rupr. (Berberidaceae); Diptacus mengdaensis sp. n. on Lonicera elisae
   Franch. (Caprifoliaceae); Rhyncaphytoptus spinus sp. n. on Lonicera
   rupicola Hook. f. et homs. (Caprifoliaceae). Aculops ulmi Hong&Xue, 2005
   was re-described.

PM 22679386
DT Article
TI The velvet spiders: an atlas of the Eresidae (Arachnida, Araneae).
AU Miller, Jeremy A. (jeremy.miller@ncbnaturalis.nl) 
   Griswold, Charles E.
   Scharff, Nikolaj
   Rezac, Milan
   Szuts, Tamas
   Marhabaie, Mohammad
SO ZooKeys
VL 195
PS 1-144
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/J_FILES/1/articles/2342/2342-G-3-layout.pdf
AW http://www.pensoft.net/J_FILES/1/articles/2342/2342-G-3-layout.pdf
LA English
U1 1
U2 18
AB The family Eresidae C. L. Koch, 1850 is reviewed at the genus level. The
   family comprises nine genera including one new genus. They are: Adonea
   Simon, 1873, Dorceus C. L. Koch, 1846, Dresserus Simon, 1876, Eresus
   Walckenaer, 1805, Gandanameno Lehtinen, 1967, Loureedia gen. n.,
   Paradonea Lawrence, 1968, Seothyra Purcell, 1903, and Stegodyphus Simon,
   1873. A key to all genera and major lineages is provided along with
   corresponding diagnoses, as well as descriptions of selected species.
   These are documented with collections of photographs, scanning electron
   micrographs, and illustrations. A new phylogeny of Eresidae based on
   molecular sequence data expands on a previously published analysis. A
   species of the genus Paradonea Lawrence, 1968 is sequenced and placed
   phylogenetically for the frst time. New sequences from twenty
   Gandanameno Lehtinen, 1967 specimens were added to investigate species
   limits within the genus. The genus Loureedia gen. n. is proposed to
   accommodate Eresus annulipes Lucas, 1857. Two species, Eresus semicanus
   Simon, 1908 and Eresus jerbae El-Hennawy, 2005, are synonymized with
   Loureedia annulipes comb. n. One new species, Paradonea presleyi sp. n.
   is described. Eresus algericus El-Hennawy, 2004 is transferred to Adonea
   Simon, 1873. The female of Dorceus fastuosus C. L. Koch, 1846 is
   described for the first time. The first fgures depicting Paradonea
   splendens (Lawrence, 1936) are presented.
C1 Miller, Jeremy A.; Department of Terrestrial Zoology, Netherlands Centre
   for Biodiversity Naturalis, Postbus 9517, 2300RA Leiden, Netherlands,
   Netherlands.
EM jeremy.miller@ncbnaturalis.nl

   Tamas/A-8241-2011
OI Miller, Jeremy/0000-0001-8918-9775; Scharff,
   Nikolaj/0000-0001-6809-2878; Szuts, Tamas/0000-0001-8954-0641
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Description;
   Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; General
   morphology; Appendages; Evolution; Land zones; Afrotropical region;
   Africa
DE Eresidae [Spinnerets / Spigot morphology / taxonomy] [Phylogeny /
   Phylogenetic history / ]. 
   Paradonea presleyi [South Africa /  / New species] [Zimbabwe /  / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae
OR Adonea algericus - (El-Hennawy 2004) (Araneae): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Eresus, p. 31].

   p. 47].

DT Article
TI Perlesta ephelida, a new Nearctic stonefly species (Plecoptera,
   Perlidae).
AU Grubbs, Scott A. (scott.grubbs@wku.edu) 
   DeWalt, R. Edward
SO ZooKeys
VL 194
PS 1-15
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/194/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4527&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new Nearctic species of Perlidae (Insecta, Plecoptera), Perlesta
   ephelida sp. n., is described from the male, female, and egg stages. his
   species has been previously reported as, or confused with, P. shubuta
   Stark from several central and eastern U.S. states. Perlesta ephelida is
   distinctive from P. shubuta and other regional Nearctic congeners mainly
   according to male genitalic and egg characteristics. Perlesta ephelida
   is a widely-distributed eastern Nearctic species, whereas P. shubuta
   appears to be restricted to a narrow latitudinal belt in the Gulf Coast
   region from Louisiana east conservatively to the Florida panhandle. he
   egg of P. shubuta is depicted with scanning electron microscopy for the
   irst time.
C1 Grubbs, Scott A.; Department of Biology and Center for Biodiversity
   Studies, Western Kentucky University, Bowling Green, KY 42101, USA, USA.
EM scott.grubbs@wku.edu
SC Zoology

   zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA

   [Ohio /  / ] [West Virginia /  / ] [Wisconsin /  / ].

AB Type material of 41 Australian Bothriembryon taxa present in Australian
   museums is critically listed, indicating systematic issues that need to
   be resolved in further studies. Information on additional type material
   of 22 taxa in non-Australian museums is compiled. he seven fossil taxa
   known so far are included in this catalogue. Based on the current
   systematic position, 38 species are treated in this paper. B. jacksoni
   Iredale, 1939, B. notatus Iredale, 1939, B. praecelsus Iredale, 1939 and
   B. serpentinus Iredale, 1939 are elevated to species level. B. gratwicki
   (Cox, 1899) is listed as status to be determined.

TI A new species of Oileus Kaup (Coleoptera, Passalidae) from Guatemala,
   with a key to the species of the genus.
AU Cano, Enio B. (ecano@uvg.edu.gt) 
   Schuster, Jack C.
SO ZooKeys
VL 194
PS 81-87
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/194/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4539&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Oileus gasparilomi sp. n. is described from nine specimens from the
   mountains of Quiche in Guatemala, from cloud forest at 1795 m elevation.
   his represents the second species of the genus for Guatemala, differing
   from the closely related Mexican species Oileus rimator (Truqui) in
   having a straight anterior clypeal border, the postocular sulcus divided
   by a keel and the pronotum almost straight (not clearly bilobed). A key
   to the species of Oileus is given.

TI Amphipoda (Crustacea) from Palau, Micronesia: families Ampeliscidae,
   Ampithoidae, Aoridae, Colomastigidae and Cyproideidae.
AU Myers, Alan A. (bavayia@googlemail.com) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 193
PS 1-25
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/193/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4500&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB 12 species of amphipod in 5 families, collected from shallow reefs in
   Palau by S. DeGrave during 2002, are reported here. Of these, ive
   species are new to science and Microdeutopus tridens Schellenberg (1938)
   is redescribed and transferred to the genus Bemlos Shoemaker (1925). he
   collection included several additional species in the genera Amphilochus
   Bate, 1862, Ampithoe Leach (1814), Bemlos, Byblis Boeck (1871),
   Colomastix Grube (1861) and Notopoma Lowry&Berents (1996), that were
   either incomplete or juvenile and could therefore not adequately be
   described. In addition, two new species of Plumithoe Barnard&Karaman
   (1991) are erected from the literature. Other families collected in
   Palau will be considered in later contributions.

PT J
AN ZOOR14807051085
DT Article
TI Two new species of the interstitial genus Parvocythere (Crustacea,
   Ostracoda, Cytheroidea) from Japan: an example of morphological
   variation.
AU Higashi, Ryouichi (downtheinterstitialworld@gmail.com) 
   Tsukagoshi, Akira
SO ZooKeys
VL 193
PS 27-48
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/193/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4503&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of the interstitial ostracod genus Parvocythere, P.
   gottwaldi sp. n. and P. gracilis sp. n., are herein described. Although
   these two new species are clearly distinguishable by certain
   morphological diferences in elements of the male copulatory organ, and
   the carapace, they share the following simpliied characters of the
   appendages and male copulatory organ: antennular fourth podomere with no
   suture; re- duced claws on the distal end of antenna; and asymmetric
   male copulatory organ. he morphological dif- ferences among known and
   new Parvocythere species suggest that the species of this genus can be
   classiied into two groups by the presence/absence of the suture on the
   antennular fourth podomere. he "Group S" is characterised by the
   presence of the antennular suture, and all species of this group have a
   two-clawed antenna and symmetric male copulatory organ, characters which
   are generally seen in cytheroid ostra- cods. he species belonging to
   "Group N" are characterised by the absence of the suture, regarded as a
   pedomorphic character, show the following characters: two clawed or one
   clawed antenna, and symmetric or asymmetric male copulatory organ. he
   morphological variation within Group N includes reductive characters
   regarded as an adaptation to the narrow spaces of the interstitial
   environment of a sandy beach. hese intrageneric morphological variations
   of the exclusively interstitial genus Parvocythere suggest the
   possibilities that Group N might be derived from Group S, and that some
   adaptive characters to an inter- stitial environment could have
   developed after the colonisation of these environments.
C1 Higashi, Ryouichi; Department of Geosciences, Faculty of Science,
   Shizuoka University, Oya 836, Shizuoka City, 422-8529, Japan, Japan.
EM downtheinterstitialworld@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Evolution; Variation;
   Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Parvocythere [Evolution / Evolutionary trends / systematics]
   [Morphological variation /  / ] [North Pacific / Japan / ]. 
   Parvocythere gottwaldi; Parvocythere gracilis [North Pacific / Japan /
   New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Ostracoda
OR Parvocythere - Hartmann 1959 (Ostracoda): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 43]. 
   Parvocythere gottwaldi (Ostracoda): [Sp nov, Japan (marine), P. 29]. 
   Parvocythere gracilis (Ostracoda): [Sp nov, Japan (marine), P. 36].

AN ZOOR14807051086
DT Article
TI Review of the Southeast Asian species of the Aenictus javanus and
   Aenictus philippinensis species groups (Hymenoptera, Formicidae,
   Aenictinae).
AU Jaitrong, Weeyawat (polyrhachis@yahoo.com) 
   Yamane, Seiki
SO ZooKeys
VL 193
PS 49-78
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/193/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4506&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Southeast Asian species of the Aenictus javanus and Aenictus
   philippinensis groups are revised. Six species (four named and two new
   species) of the Aenictus javanus group occurring in this area are: A.
   doydeei Jaitrong&Yamane, 2011, A. duengkaei Jaitrong&Yamane, sp. n., A.
   javanus Emery, 1896, A. longinodus Jaitrong&Yamane, sp. n., A.
   nishimurai Terayama&Kubota, 1993, and A. piercei Wheeler&Chapman, 1930.
   Four species (three named and one new species) are recognized in the
   Aenictus philippinensis group: A. pangantihoni Zettel&Sorger, 2010, A.
   philippinensis Chapman, 1963, A. punctatus Jaitrong&Yamane, sp. n., and
   A. rabori Chapman, 1963. A. piercei is removed from the members of the
   A. piercei group sensu Jaitrong and Yamane (2011) and transferred to the
   A. javanus group. Lectotypes and paralectotypes are designated for A.
   piercei and A. rabori. Size variation occurs among individuals from
   single colonies of the A. javanus group, while the workers in the A.
   philippinensis group are clearly monomorphic.

   Museum, Technopolis, Khlong 5, Khlong Luang, Pathum Thani, 12120,
   Thailand, Thailand.

TI Lithobius (Monotarsobius) monoforaminis sp. n., a new species of
   lithobiid centipede from central China (Chilopoda, Lithobiomorpha,
   Lithobiidae).
AU Ma, Huiqin (mhq008@yahoo.com) 
   Pei, Sujian
   Wu, Dayong
   Lin, Hongjun
   Gai, Yonghua
SO ZooKeys
VL 193
PS 79-87
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/193/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4509&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The present paper describes a new species Lithobius (Monotarsobius)
   monoforaminis sp. n. (Lithobiomorpha: Lithobiidae) recently discovered
   from Shaanxi and Shanxi provinces, Central China. Morphologically it
   resembles L. (M.) minimus Farzalieva, 2006 from Eastern Kazakhstan, but
   could be well distinguished from the latter having only one pore on the
   coxae of legs 12-15 and diferent plectrotaxy, and by lacking a wart on
   the male tibia 15. A key to the Chinese Lithobius (Monotarsobius)
   species is presented.

DT Article
TI Review of Chinese Oligaphorurini (Collembola, Onychiuridae) with
   descriptions of two new Palaearctic species.
AU Xin Sun (wudonghui@neigae.ac.cn) 
   Wu, Donghui
SO ZooKeys
VL 192
PS 15-26
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/192/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4485&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A checklist of Chinese Oligaphorurini is given. Two new Chinese species,
   Micraphorura changbaiensis sp. n. and Oligaphorura pseudomontana sp. n.,
   are described from Changbai Mountain Range. M. changbaiensis sp. n. has
   the same dorsal pseudocelli formula and number of papillae in Ant. III
   sensory organ as M. uralica, but they can be easily distinguished by
   number of chaetae in Ant. III sensory organ, ventral pseudocelli
   formula, ventral parapseudocelli formula, number of pseudocelli on
   subcoxa 1 of legs I-III, dorsal axial chaeta on Abd. V and number of
   chaetae on tibiotarsi. O. pseudomontana sp. n. is very similar to the
   species O. montana having an increased number of pseudocelli on body
   dorsally, well marked base of antenna with 1 pseudocellus and 3
   pseudocelli outside, subcoxa 1 of legs I-III with 1 pseudocellus each,
   dorsally S-chaetae formula as 11/011/22211 from head to Abd. V,
   S-microchaeta present on h. II-III, claw without inner teeth and with
   1+1 lateral teeth, and unguiculus with basal lamella; but they can be
   separated easily by the number of pseudocelli on Abd. V and VI terga,
   parapseudocelli on the body, number of chaetae on h. I tergum, and
   number of chaetae on tibiotarsi. A key to Chinese species of
   Oligaphorurini is provided in the present paper.
C1 Xin Sun; Key Laboratory of Wetland Ecology and Environment, Northeast
   Institute of Geography and Agroecology, Chinese Academy of Sciences,
   Changchun 130012, China, China.
EM wudonghui@neigae.ac.cn

SN 1313-2970

   Publications; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

   species].

   [Jilin /  / ]. 
   Oligaphorurini [Checklists /  / ] [China /  / ] [ /  / Key to species].

DT Article
TI Description and DNA barcoding of Tipula (Pterelachisus) recondita sp. n.
   from the Palaearctic region (Diptera, Tipulidae).
AU Pilipenko, Valentin E.
   Salmela, Jukka (jueesal@utu.fi) 
   Vesterinen, Eero J.
SO ZooKeys
VL 192
PS 51-65
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/192/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=4494&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB Tipula (Pterelachisus) recondita Pilipenko&Salmela, sp. n. is described.
   he new species is collected from two localities: Finland, Kittila (North
   boreal ecoregion) and Russia, Primorski kray (Zone of temperate
   broadleaf and mixed forests). Although variation in the structure of
   male hypopygium between the Finnish and Russian populations is observed,
   DNA barcode sequences difer only by three nucleotides (0.2 % K2P
   distance), supporting presence of one widespread species. K2P minimum
   distances between the new species and 17 other species of the subgenus
   range from 5.3 to 15.8 % (mean 8.8 %). he new species is
   forest-dwelling, known from an old-growth herb-rich forest (Finland) and
   Quercus mongolica forest (Russia). he new species is perhaps closest to
   T. (P.) imitator Alexander and in lesser extent to T. (P.) pauli
   Mannheims; the inner gonostylus of both species are illustrated.
C1 Salmela, Jukka; Zoological Museum, Department of Biology, FI-20014
   University of Turku, Finland, Finland.
EM jueesal@utu.fi
RI Vesterinen, Eero J./Q-9527-2019; Vesterinen, Eero/I-6638-2012

   Eero/0000-0003-3665-5802
