DT Article
TI Two new genera and two new species of Mantophasmatodea (Insecta,
   Polyneoptera) from Namibia.
AU Wipfler, Benjamin (benjamin.wipfer@uni-jena.de) 
   Pohl, Hans
   Predel, Reinhard
SO ZooKeys
VL 166
PS 75-98
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/166/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=3818&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Two new species and two new genera (Pachyphasma, Striatophasma) of
   Mantophasmatodea are described from Namibia. Pachyphasma brandbergense
   is endemic to the Brandberg massif; Striatophasma occupies an extensive
   area south of the region inhabited by Mantophasma. Phylogenetic analyses
   (see Predel et al. in press) suggest a sistergroup relationship of
   Striatophasma and the South African Austrophasmatidae.
C1 Wipfler, Benjamin; Entomology Group, Institut fuer Spezielle Zoologie
   and Evolutionsbiologie, Friedrich-Schiller-University Jena, Erbertstr.
   1, 07743 Jena, Germany, Germany.
EM benjamin.wipfer@uni-jena.de
RI Predel, Reinhard/O-5243-2015; Wipfler, Benjamin/M-2926-2015; Pohl,
   Hans/M-6873-2019
OI Pohl, Hans/0000-0002-7090-6612
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Pachyphasma brandbergense; Striatophasma naukluftense [Namibia /  / New
   species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Mantophasmatodea

   naukluftense, p. 77].

AB Five new species of the Stenus indubius group from China are described:
   S. cangshanus sp. n. from Yunnan Province, S. hewenjiae sp. n. from
   Sichuan Province, S. taiyangshanus sp. n. from Guangdong Province, S.
   yinziweii sp. n. and S. zhaiyanbini sp. n. from Guizhou Province.
   Diagnostic characters are illustrated and a key to the species of this
   group from the Chinese mainland is provided.

DT Article
TI Two new species of Quedius Stephens, subgenus Raphirus Stephens from
   Yunnan, Southwest China (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Staphylinini).
AU Hu, Jia-Yao (hujiayaonazeris@gmail.com) 
   Li, Li-Zhen
   Cao, Guang-Hong
SO ZooKeys
VL 165
PS 47-55
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/165/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=3809&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Two new species of the genus Quedius Stephens collected from Nabanhe
   Nature Reserve, Yunnan Province, Q. nabanhensis sp. n. and Q. maoxingi
   sp. n., are described and illustrated. Keys to the multipunctatus group
   and intricatus group of Quedius species of Yunnan are provided. A map of
   the collecting sites is given.

   Shanghai, 100 Guilin Road, Shanghai, 200234, China, China.

PT J
AN ZOOR14804027025
PM 22328857
DT Article
TI Cuban Calisto (Lepidoptera, Nymphalidae, Satyrinae), a review based on
   morphological and DNA data.
AU Aguila, Rayner Nunez (rayner@ecologia.cu) 
   Plasencia, Edelquis Oliva
   Matos Maravi, Pavel F.
   Wahlberg, Niklas
SO ZooKeys
VL 165
PS 57-105
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/165/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=3805&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The Cuban species of Calisto are reviewed based on the morphology of
   adult and immature stages, as well as DNA sequences of six genes (COI,
   EF1a, wingless, GAPDH, RpS5, CAD). A new species, Calisto occulta sp.
   n., is described from the northeastern Cuban mountains. Calisto
   smintheus Bates, 1935 and C. bruneri, Michener 1949 are revised and
   revalidated. A new status, the species level, is proposed for C.
   brochei, Torre 1973, C. muripetens, Bates 1939 and C. bradleyi, Munroe
   1950. The immature stages of C. smintheus, C. brochei, and C. occulta
   are described for the irst time, and those of C. herophile, Hubner 1823
   are redescribed. Useful morphological characters for adults are the
   shape and conspicuousness of androconial patch, the number and relative
   size of white dots on underside of hindwing, the shape of aedeagus, the
   shape of digitiform projection of genitalia valve, the shape and
   relative size of tegumen and uncus, the relative size of female
   genitalia, the height of sterigmal ring dorsal crown of the latter, and
   the relative size of corpus bursae and ductus bursae. For the immature
   stages, the most important characters are the color pattern of head
   capsule, the number and width of longitudinal lines of body, in the
   larvae; and the color pattern and the absence or presence of dorsal
   ridges on the abdomen of pupae. The phylogenetic relationships between
   the Cuban Calisto species are quite robust and well-supported; however,
   conlict between mitochondrial and nuclear datasets was detected in C.
   brochei, C. muripetens and to a lesser degree in C. bradleyi.
C1 Aguila, Rayner Nunez; Division de Colecciones Zoologicas y Sistematica,
   Instituto de Ecologia y Sistematica, Carretera de Varona, km 3.5,
   Capdevila, Boyeros, Ciudad de La Habana, Cuba, Cuba.
EM rayner@ecologia.cu
RI Matos-Maravi, Pavel/O-6626-2017; Wahlberg, Niklas/B-7765-2008
OI Matos-Maravi, Pavel/0000-0002-2885-4919; Wahlberg,
   Niklas/0000-0002-1259-3363
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1313-2970

   Biometrics; General morphology; Genetics; Evolution; Variation; Land
   zones; Neotropical region; Central America; West Indies

DT Article
TI Five new species of the genera Heerz Marsh, Lissopsius Marsh and Ondigus
   Braet, Barbalho and van Achterberg (Braconidae, Doryctinae) from the
   Chamela-Cuixmala biosphere reserve in Jalisco, Mexico.
AU Zaldivar-Riveron, Alejandro (azaldivar@ibiologia.unam.mx) 
   Martinez, Juan Jose
   Ceccarelli, Fadia Sara
   Shaw, Scott R.
SO ZooKeys
VL 164
PS 1-23
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/2201/abstract/five-new-s
   pecies-of-the-genera-heerz-marsh-lissopsius-marsh-and-ondigus-braet-barb
   alho-and-van-achterberg-braconidae-dor
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB Five new species belonging to the poorly known Neotropical doryctine
   parasitoid wasps genera Heerz Marsh (H. ecmahla sp. n. and H.
   macrophthalma sp. n.), Lissopsius Marsh (L. pacificus sp. n. and L.
   jalisciensis sp. n.) and Ondigus Braet, Barbalho & van Achterberg (O.
   cuixmalensis sp. n.) are described from the Chamela-Cuixmala Biosphere
   reserve in Jalisco, Mexico. Keys to the described species of the above
   three genera are provided. The phylogenetic placement of the examined
   taxa is investigated based on mi- tochondrial (COI) and nuclear (28S,
   2nd and 3rd domain regions) DNA sequence data.

DT Article
TI Female genitalia of Seasogonia Young from China, with a new synonym and
   a new record (Hemiptera, Cicadellidae, Cicadellini).
AU Meng, Ze-hong (yangmaofa@sohu.com) 
   Yang, Mao-fa
SO ZooKeys
VL 164
PS 25-40
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/2132/abstract/female-gen
   italia-of-seasogonia-young-from-china-with-a-new-synonym-and-a-new-recor
   d-hemiptera-cicadellidae-cicadellini-
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Seasogonia Young, 1986 is a sharpshooter genus with 13 species, four of
   them recorded from China. In this paper, S. sandaracata (Distant, 1908)
   is recorded as new for China and S. ruipenna Li & Wang, 1992 is regarded
   as a junior synonym of S. nigromaculata Kuoh, 1991. he morphological
   diversity of the female genitalia of Seasogonia is still poorly known.
   We provide herein detailed descriptions and illustrations of three
   Chinese Seasogonia species. Notes on the female genitalia of Seasogonia,
   including intraspeciic and interspeciic variation, and comparisons
   between the female genitalia of Seasogonia and of other related genera
   from China are provided. he preliminary results indicate that the female
   genitalia may provide useful features for the taxonomy of Seasogonia and
   other members of the Old World Cicadellini.
C1 Meng, Ze-hong; Institute of Entomology, Guizhou University; the
   Provincial Key Laboratory for Agricultural Pest Management of
   Mountainous Region, Guiyang, Guizhou, 550025, China, China.
EM yangmaofa@sohu.com

   Reproductive system; Evolution; Variation; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia; China

   [Morphological variation /  / ] [China /  / ]. 
   Seasogonia sandaracata [China /  / New record] [Xizang /  / ] [Yunnan / 
   / ].

DT Article
TI Orthogonius species and diversity in Thailand (Coleoptera, Caraboidea,
   Orthogoniini), a result from the TIGER project.
AU Tian, Mingyi (mytian168@yahoo.com.cn) 
   Deuve, Thierry
   Felix, Ron
SO ZooKeys
VL 164
PS 51-90
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/article/1992/abstract/orthogoniu
   s-species-and-diversity-in-thailand-coleoptera-caraboidea-orthogoniini-a
   -result-from-the-tiger-project
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The carabid genus Orthogonius MacLeay is treated, based mainly on
   materials collected in Thailand through the TIGER project (the Thailand
   Inventory Group for Entomological Research). Among 290 specimens, 20
   species are identiied in total, 10 of them are new species: O.
   taghavianae sp. n. (Nakhon Nayok: Khao Yai National Park), O.
   coomanioides sp. n. (Phetchabun: Thung Salaeng Luang National Park), O.
   similaris sp. n. (Phetchabun: Thung Salaeng Luang National Park; Loei:
   Phu Kradueng National Park), O. setosopalpiger sp. n. (Phetchabun: Thung
   Salaeng Luang National Park), O. gracililamella sp. n. (Loei: Phu
   Kradueng National Park; Chaiyaphum: Tat Tone National Park), O.
   pseudochaudoiri sp. n. (Phetchabum: Thung Salaeng Luang National Park;
   Nakhon Nayok: Khao Yai National Park), O. constrictus sp. n.
   (Phetchabum: Thung Salaeng Luang National Park), O. pinophilus sp. n.
   (Phetchabum: Thung Salaeng Luang National Park), O. vari sp. n.
   (Cambodia: Siem Reap; Thailand: Ubon Ratchathani: Pha Taem National
   Park; Phetchabun: hung Salaeng Luang National Park) and O. variabilis
   sp. n. (hailand: Phetchabun: hung Salaeng Luang National Park; Nakhon
   Nayok: Khao Yai National Park; Phetchabun: Nam Nao National Park; China:
   Yunnan). In addition, O. mouhoti Chaudoir, 1871 and O. kirirom Tian &
   Deuve, 2008 are recorded in hailand for the first time. In total, 30
   species of Orthogonius have been recorded from Thailand, indicating that
   hailand holds one of the richest Orthogonius faunas in the world. A
   provisional key to all Thai species is provided. A majority of Thai
   Orthogonius species are endemic. Among the ten national parks in which
   orthogonine beetles were collected, Thung Salaeng Luang holds the
   richest fauna, including 16 species.

   Environment, South China Agricultural University, Guangzhou, Guangdong
   510640, China, China.
EM mytian168@yahoo.com.cn

DT Article
TI A troglomorphic spider from Java (Araneae, Ctenidae, Amauropelma).
AU Miller, Jeremy (jeremy.miller@ncbnaturalis.nl) 
   Rahmadi, Cahyo
SO ZooKeys
VL 163
PS 1-11
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/163/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=3741[integral]il
   eTable=J_GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A new troglomorphic spider from caves in Central Java, Indonesia, is
   described and placed in the ctenid genus Amauropelma Raven, Stumkat &
   Gray, until now containing only species from Queensland, Australia. Only
   juveniles and mature females of the new species are known. We give our
   reasons for placing the new species in Amauropelma, discuss conflicting
   characters, and make predictions about the morphology of the as yet
   undiscovered male that will test our taxonomic hypothesis. The
   description includes DNA barcode sequence data.
C1 Miller, Jeremy; Department of Entomology, Netherlands Centre for
   Biodiversity Naturalis, Postbus 9517, 2300 RA Leiden, Netherlands,
   Netherlands.

   Japan. Part I: ascidian-dwellers.

U1 0

AB Commensal leucothoid amphipods have been collected from the branchial
   chambers of their ascidian hosts throughout the Ryukyu Archipelago,
   Japan. Seven new species are described in two genera with valuable
   location data and host records. An identification key to
   ascidian-dwelling Leucothoidae of the Ryukyu Archipelago is provided.

DT Article
TI Description of a new species of Platynus Bonelli from the Appalachian
   Mountains of eastern North America (Coleoptera, Carabidae).
AU Bousquet, Yves (yves.bousquet@agr.gc.ca) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 163
PS 69-81
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/163/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=3751[integral]il
   eTable=J_GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species of the genus Platynus Bonelli, P. daviesi, is described
   from specimens collected in the Appalachian Mountains. The species is
   structurally most similar to P. parmarginatus Hamilton but differs in
   having the coloration of the body dorsally darker on average, the elytra
   proportionally longer and wider, the vertex and disc of pronotum with
   well impressed microsculpture, the elytral interval 3 with four or five
   discal setae in most specimens, and the median lobe of aedeagus less
   curved overall. DNA barcoding was performed on several species of
   eastern North American Platynus species and P. daviesi was found to be
   genetically distinct from P. parmarginatus. A key to the 12 species of
   Platynus found east of the Mississippi River is provided.
C1 Bousquet, Yves; Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, K1A
   0C6, Canada, Canada.
EM yves.bousquet@agr.gc.ca
SC Genetics &Heredity; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology

   Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA

   Molecular phylogeny / ] [Variation / Genetic variation / ] [North

TI Discovery of the genus Meggoleus Townes, 1971 (Hymenoptera,
   Ichneumonidae, Tersilochinae) in Peru, with the description of two new
   species.
AU Alvarado, Mabel (malvarado@ku.edu) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 163
PS 83-90
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/163/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=3754[integral]il
   eTable=J_GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Meggoleus Townes, 1971 (Ichneumonidae, Tersilochinae)
   currently comprises two species, one from Brazil and one from Gabon. The
   genus is recorded from Peru for the first time, with a range extension
   of the type species, Meggoleus spirator Townes, 1971, and the discovery
   of two new species [long dash] Meggoleus fuscatus sp. n. and Meggoleus
   pampahermosensis sp. n. A key to the world's species is provided.

DT Article
TI Review of the Nearctic genus Lacconotus LeConte (Coleoptera, Mycteridae,
   Eurypinae).
AU Pollock, Darren
   Majka, Christopher G. (c.majka@ns.sympatico.ca) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 162
PS 1-24
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/162/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=3731&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Lacconotus LeConte, the sole Nearctic representative of the eurypine
   Mycteridae, is revised, based on morphological features of adults. The
   following syn. n. is proposed: L. pallidus Van Dyke, 1928 = L. pinicola
   Horn 1879. The former is a light-colored form with a southern California
   distribution. A subgen. n., Alcconotus, is described for L. pinicola,
   producing the following comb. n.: Lacconotus (Alcconotus) pinicola
   (Horn). A lectotype is designated for L. pinicola. A key separating the
   two subgenera and species is provided, as are photographs and
   illustrations of salient structures of adults, and maps showing
   collection localities. Lacconotus punctatus is newly recorded in
   Alabama, Arkansas, Massachusetts, Oklahoma, Texas, and Wisconsin; L.
   pinicola is newly recorded in Arizona and Utah in the USA, and Baja
   California Norte in Mexico. Phenology information shows a north-to-south
   gradation in occurrence time.
C1 Majka, Christopher G.; Nova Scotia Museum, 1747 Summer Street, Halifax,
   Nova Scotia, Canada, Canada.
EM c.majka@ns.sympatico.ca
OI Pollock, Darren/0000-0002-8709-0269
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970

   Description; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; USA

   record] [Arizona /  / ] [Utah /  / ]. 
   Lacconotus (Lacconotus) punctatus [Alabama /  / New record] [Arkansas / 
   / ] [Massachusetts /  / ] [Oklahoma /  / ] [Texas /  / ] [Wisconsin /  /
   ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates

   Mycteridae

   subgenera, Nearctic region, P. 4; Key to species, Nearctic region, P.
   4]. 
   Lacconotus (Alcconotus) (Mycteridae): [Subgen nov, Type species
   Lacconotus pinicola Horn 1879, p. 12].

DT Article
TI Rove beetle subtribes Quediina, Amblyopinina and Tanygnathinina:
   systematic changes affecting Central European fauna (Coleoptera,
   Staphylinidae, Staphylinini).
AU Solodovnikov, Alexey (asolodovnikov@snm.ku.dk) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 162
PS 25-42
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/162/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=3734&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB In preparation for the new edition of the identifcation keys of rove
   beetles of Central Europe (Volume 4 of the "Die Kaefer Mitteleuropas"),
   the following systematic problems affecting the Central European fauna
   of the tribe Staphylinini are addressed: phylogeny-based, new concepts
   for the subtribes Quediina and Amblyopinina; status of the subtribe
   Tanygnathinina; systematic position of the genus Astrapaeus; status of
   Quedionuchus, the subgenus of Quedius; identity of some species of
   Quedius and Heterothops. As a result, new wordwide and Central Europe-
   based diagnoses are given for the subtribes Quediina and Amblyopinina;
   earlier recognized but not widely accepted synonymies of the genera
   Quedius and Velleius, and of the species Heterothops praevius and H.
   niger, are justifed; new synonyms are established for: Quedius
   pseudonigriceps Reitter, 1909 (= Quedius noricus Bernhauer, 1927, syn.
   n.); Quedius maurorufus (Gravenhorst, 1806) (= Quedius richteri Korge,
   1966, syn. n.); Quedius suturalis Kiesenwetter, 1845 (= Quedius merlini
   Drugmand & Bruge 1991, syn. n.); lectotypes are designated for Quedius
   meridiocarpathicus Smetana, 1958, Quedius noricus Bernhauer, 1927, and
   Quedius pseudonigriceps Reitter, 1909. As a result of synonymy of
   Quedius and Velleius, the following new combinations are proposed:
   Quedius amamiensis (Watanabe, 1990), comb. n.; Quedius circumipectus
   (Cho, 1996), comb. n.; Quedius elongatus (Naomi, 1986), comb. n.;
   Quedius japonicus (Watanabe, 1990), comb. n.; Quedius pectinatus (Sharp,
   1874), comb. n.; Quedius setosus (Sharp, 1889), comb. n.; Quedius
   simillimus (Fairmaire, 1891), comb. n. As a result of new combinations,
   Quedius japonicus (Watanabe, 1990) (non Quedius japonicus Sharp, 1874)
   is replaced with the new name Quedius watanabei Solodovnikov, nom. n.,
   while Quedius pectinatus Lea, 1908 (non Quedius pectinatus (Sharp,
   1874)) is replaced with the new name Quedius arthuri Solodovnikov, nom.
   n.

   (Natural History Museum of Denmark), Universitetsparken 15, Copenhagen
   2100, Denmark, Denmark.

DT Article
TI Revision of Tipula (Yamatotipula) stackelbergi Alexander (Diptera,
   Tipulidae), and a short discussion on subspecies among crane flies.
AU Salmela, Jukka (jueesal@utu.fi) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 162
PS 43-58
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/162/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/inc/journals/download.php?fileId=3735&fileTable=J
   _GALLEYS
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB All available type material of Tipula stackelbergi Alexander, T.
   usuriensis Alexander and T. subpruinosa Mannheims were examined. Tipula
   (Yamatotipula) stackelbergi stat. rev. is elevated from a subspecies of
   T. (Y.) pruinosa Wiedemann to a valid species. Two new synonyms are
   proposed: Tipula usuriensis syn. n. proved to be a junior synonym of. T.
   (Y.) pruinosa and T. subpruinosa syn. n. a junior synonym of T. (Y.)
   freyana Lackschewitz. Tipula (Y.) stackelbergi is redescribed, male and
   female terminalia of T. (Y.) pruinosa are illustrated and discussed.
   Female terminalia of T. (Y.) freyana are described and illustrated for
   the frst time. A key to both sexes of T. (Y.) stackelbergi and T. (Y.)
   pruinosa, and a key to females of T. (Y.) chon- saniana, T. (Y.) freyana
   and T. (Y.) moesta are provided. Subspecies are not uncommon among crane
   fies, but their ranges and traits are poorly known. An interdisciplinary
   approach (genetics, ecology, taxonomy) is suggested if subspecifc ranks
   are to be used in tipuloid systematics.
C1 Salmela, Jukka; Zoological Museum, Department of Biology, FI-20014
   University of Turku, Finland, Finland.
EM jueesal@utu.fi
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970

   Status
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Nematocera, Tipulidae
OR Tipula (Yamatotipula) chonsaniana - Alexander (Tipulidae): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 55]. 
   Tipula (Yamatotipula) freyana - Lackschewitz 1936 (Tipulidae):
   [Diagnostic characters, P. 55; Description, P. 52; Syn nov, Tipula
   (Tipula) subpruinosa Mannheims 1954, p. 52]. 
   Tipula (Yamatotipula) moesta - Riedel (Tipulidae): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 55]. 
   Tipula (Yamatotipula) pruinosa - Wiedemann 1817 (Tipulidae): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 53; Redescription, P. 49; Syn nov, Tipula usuriensis

   [Diagnostic characters, P. 53; Redescription, P. 46; Raised from, Tipula
   (Yamatotipula) pruinosa stackelberg, p. 45].

DT Article
TI Revision of New World Species of the Shore-fly Subgenus Allotrichoma
   Becker of the Genus Allotrichoma with Description of the Subgenus
   Neotrichoma (Diptera, Ephydridae, Hecamedini).
AU Mathis, Wayne N. (mathisw@si.edu) 
   Zatwarnicki, Tadeusz
SO ZooKeys
VL 161
SU (Special Issue)
PS 1-101
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/161/
AW http://www.pensoft.net/journals/zookeys/issue/161/
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The New World species of the subgenera Allotrichoma Becker and
   Neotrichoma (new subgenus) are revised, including a phylogenetic
   analysis of the species groups and subgenera within the genus
   Allotrichoma. For phylogenetic perspective and to document the monophyly
   of the genus Allotrichoma and its included subgenera and species groups,
   we also provide a cladistic analysis of genera within the tribe
   Hecamedini. The ingroup included seven exemplar congeners from within
   Allotrichoma. Outgroup sampling included exemplars of other genera
   within Hecamedini and from the putative sister group, Lipochaetini, and
   to root the analysis, we used an exemplar of the tribe Discocerinini.
   Analyses with successive weighting and implied weighting recovered a
   monophyletic Allotrichoma and indicated clades within the genus. Eight
   new species are described (type locality in parenthesis): A. bifurcatum
   (Utah. Utah: Lake Shore (40[degree]06.9[minute]N,
   111[degree]41.8[minute]W; 1370 m)), A. dynatum (Oregon. Benton: Finley
   National Wildlife Refuge (44[degree]24.6[minute]N,
   123[degree]19.5[minute]W)), A. occidentale (Oregon. Lake: Lakeview (44
   km E; Drake Creek; 42[degree]11[minute]N, 119[degree]59.3[minute]W)), A.
   robustum (California. Kern: Kern River (35[degree]16.1[minute]N,
   119[degree]18.4[minute]W)), A. sabroskyi (New Mexico. Sandoval: La Cueva
   (Junction of Highways 126 and 4; 35[degree]52'N,
   106[degree]38.4[minute]W; 2342 m)), A. wallowa (Oregon Baker: Goose
   Creek (35 km E Baker City; 44[degree]49.2[minute]N,
   117[degree]27.79[minute]W; 825 m)), A. baliops (Florida. Monroe: Key
   West (Willie Ward Park; 24[degree]32.9[minute]N,
   81[degree]47.9[minute])), and A. insulare (Dominica. Cabrits Swamp
   (15[degree]35[minute]N, 61[degree]29[minute]W)). Within Allotrichoma, we
   recognize three subgenera of which one, Neotrichoma (type species: A.
   atrilabre), is newly described. All known species from the New World are
   described with an emphasis on structures of the male terminalia, which
   are fully illustrated. Detailed locality data and distribution maps for
   the New World species are provided. A lectotype is designated for
   Discocerina simplex Loew and a neotype is designated for Allotrichoma
   bezzii Becker. Allotrichoma iliforme Becker, A. trispinum Becker, and A.
   dahli Beschovski are reported as new synonyms of A. simplex (Loew) and
   A. yosemite Cresson is a new synonym of A. atrilabre Cresson. We also
   clarify the status of previously described species, including those with
   Holarctic distributions. For perspective and to facilitate genus-group
   and species- group recognition, the tribe Hecamedini is diagnosed and a
   key to included genera is provided.
C1 Mathis, Wayne N.; Department of Entomology, PO Box 37012, MRC 169,
   Smithsonian Institution, Washington DC 20013-7012, USA, USA.
EM mathisw@si.edu
SC Evolutionary Biology; Zoology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Type material;
   Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key; Evolution; Land zones; Nearctic
   region; Neotropical region; North America; Canada; USA; Central America;
   West Indies; South America
DE Allotrichoma [Phylogeny /  / Systematics] [Land zones / New World /
   distribution]. 
   Allotrichoma (Allotrichoma) [Land zones / New World / Key to species]. 
   Allotrichoma (Allotrichoma) bifurcatum [British Columbia /  / New
   species] [Idaho /  / ] [Oregon /  / ] [Utah /  / ] [Washington /  / ]. 
   Allotrichoma (Allotrichoma) dynatum [British Columbia /  / New species]
   [Oregon /  / ] [Washington /  / ].

   [Saskatchewan /  / ] [Alaska /  / ] [Arizona /  / ] [California /  / ]
   [Idaho /  / ] [Michigan /  / ] [Montana /  / ] [Nebraska /  / ] [Nevada
   /  / ] [North Dakota /  / ] [Oregon /  / ] [South Dakota /  / ] [Utah /

TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Ephydridae
OR Allotrichoma - Becker 1896 (Ephydridae). 
   Allotrichoma (Allotrichoma) - Becker 1896 (Ephydridae): [Diagnosis, P.

PT J
AN ZOOR14811074677
DT Article
TI Mites Associated with the Red Palm Weevil, Rhynchophorus ferrugineus
   Oliver in Saudi Arabia with a Description of a New Species.
AU Al-Dhafar, Z.M. (moth158@yahoo.com) 
   Al-Qahtani, A.M.
SO Acarines
VL 6
PS 3-6
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The red palm weevil (RPW) Rhynchophorus ferrugineus Oliver is an
   economically important pest of palm in Al-Hassa (Eastern Province of
   Saudi Arabia). The RPW was noted associated with mites during May [long
   dash] June 2009. Three mite species were found. One of which Aegyptus
   alhassa n. sp. (Gamasida, Trachyuropodidae) as a parasite collected from
   eggs, larvae, pupae cocoons and under the elytron of insect adult was
   described. The second mite species Sejus sp. may feed on fungi or
   organic debris, while the acarid hypopial stage may feed on dead
   insects.

   Eastern Province, 31481, Saudi Arabia, Saudi Arabia.

PT J
AN ZOOR14811075050
DT Article
TI Records of insects associated with wild plants of cocuy in Lara State,
   Venezuela.
FT Registros de insectos asociados a plantas silvestres del cucuy en el
   estado Lara, Venezuela.
AU Arcaya, Evelin (aevelin@ucla.edu.ve) 
   Capote, Tarcisio
   Solano, Yohan
   Morales, Jose
SO Bioagro
VL 24
IS 1
PS 65-69
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 2
AB Studies were conducted to gain new understanding of insects associated
   to wild plants of cocuy, Agave cocui Trealease, under field and
   laboratory conditions. In the field, leaves, corms and flowers, were
   carefully examined for insect species. Collected adult insects and
   immature stages were taken to the laboratory where immature stages were
   reared until the adult stage. Specimens were then pinned, tagged, and
   deposited at the collection of the Jose M. Osorio Museum of Entomology
   (MJMO). Raymond Gagne, from the Smithonian Institute, Washington D. C.,
   and Mario Cermeli, from the National Agricultural Research Center
   (CENIAP) identified cecidomyiids and aphids, respectively. Other
   specimens were identified by comparison with the specimens deposited at
   the Museum of the Institute of Agricultural Zoology (MIZA), Universidad
   Central de Venezuela. The following species were reported: Aphis
   craccivora Koch (Hemiptera: Aphididae), Asphondylia sp. (Diptera:
   Cecidomyiidae), Chrysomphalus sp. (Hemiptera: Diaspididae), Dismycoccus
   sp. (Hemiptera: Pseudococcidae), Phidotricha erigens Ragonot
   (Lepidoptera: Pyralidae), Scyphophorus acupunctatus Gyllenhal
   (Coleoptera: Curculionidae) and Spodoptera frugiperda (J.E. Smith)
   (Lepidoptera: Noctuidae). The registration of insects that attack cocuy
   wild plants may be useful in the future for the establishment of an
   integrated pest management system.
C1 Arcaya, Evelin; Dpto. de Ciencias Biologicas, Universidad
   Centroccidental "Lisandro Alvarado", Barquisimeto, Venezuela, Venezuela.
EM aevelin@ucla.edu.ve
OI Solano Rojas, Yohan Alexander/0000-0001-9762-2815
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Nutrition &Dietetics;
   Parasitology
BD Animals and man; Nutrition; Diet; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Hosts; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Insecta [Control / Integrated pest management implications / pests] [ / 
   / host parasite list] [Food plants / Agave cocui / ] [Plant hosts /  / ]
   [Venezuela / Lara / faunal list] [ /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda
OR Insecta (Arthropoda): [Parasite]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14811075050

TI A new Cryptocephalus of the C. curvilinea - group (Coleoptera,
   Chrysomelidae) from the Atlantic coastal marshes of Southern Spain and
   Portugal.
AU Vela, Jose Miguel (josem.vela@juntadeandalucia.es) 
   Bastazo, Gloria
SO Boletin de la Asociacion Espanola de Entomologia
VL 36
IS 1-2
PS 31-41
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species, Cryptocephalus baenai, is described from the Atlantic
   coastal marshes in southern Spain and Portugal. It is closely related to
   C. muellerianus, known from eastern and south-eastern Spain, included in
   the C. curvilinea - group. Remarks on the host plant and distribution of
   the four species composing this group are made. Furthermore, a key for
   these species is provided.

   citas de acaros oribatidos (Acari: Oribatida) de Espana.
AU Subias, Luis S. (subias@bio.ucm.es) 
SO Boletin de la Asociacion Espanola de Entomologia
VL 36
IS 1-2
PS 43-52
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new name, Peloptulus ibericus n. nom., is given for Peloptulus
   phaenotus (Koch, 1844) sensu GIL&SUBIAS, 1990, and the genera:
   Cryptoplophora Grandjean, 1932, Mucronothrus Tragardh, 1931,
   Suctobelbila Jacot, 1937 and Lamellovertex Bernini, 1976 are recorded
   for the first time from Spain. Also 20 species are recorded for the
   first time to Spain, and the species Licneremaeus similis Perez-Inigo
   jr., 1990 is synonymised with Licneremaeus novus Karppinen y
   Shtanchaeva, 1987.

TI Contribution to the knowledge of the Moroccan Asidini II. Description of
   a new species of Alphasida Escalera, 1905 of the subgenus Machlasida
   Escalera, 1907 (Coleoptera, Tenebrionidae).
FT Contribucion al conocimiento de los Asidini marroquies II. Descripcion
   de una nueva especie de Alphasida Escalera, 1905 del subgenero
   Machlasida Escalera, 1907 (Coleoptera, Tenebrionidae).
AU Perez-Vera, Francisco (fperezvera@yahoo.fr) 
   Avila, Jose Miguel
SO Boletin de la Asociacion Espanola de Entomologia
VL 36
IS 1-2
PS 75-85
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this paper, we describe one new taxon of the genus Alphasida
   Escalera, 1905 that was in the collection of Tenebrionidae of the
   Hungarian Natural History Museum (HNHM) in Budapest, Alphasida
   (Machlasida) merkli sp. nov. This species belongs to the subgenus
   Machlasida Escale- ra, 1907, an entire group endemic to Morocco and
   whose taxonomic management had not been updated in nearly a century,
   until very recently in the course of the review of the tribe Asidini in
   Morocco, which we are ? nishing. The new species is close to Alphasida
   (Machlasida) acuticosta (Fairmaire, 1880) and both are easily
   distinguishable from other species of the subgenus.

DT Article
TI Checklist of the cicadas (Insecta: Hemiptera: Cicadidae) of Nicaragua
   including new records for seventeen species.
AU Sanborn, Allen F. (asanborn@mail.barry.edu) 
   Maes, Jean-Michel
SO Check List
VL 8
IS 3
PS 437-442
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.checklist.org.br/archive?vol=8&num=3
AW http://www.checklist.org.br/getpdf?SL026-11
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A current checklist of the Nicaraguan cicada fauna is provided. The
   first Nicaraguan records of Miranha imbellis (Walker, 1858),
   Diceroprocta bicosta (Walker, 1850), Diceroprocta ruatana (Distant,
   1891), Fidicina mannifera (Fabricius, 1803), Fidicinoides cachla
   (Distant, 1899), Fidicinoides pronoe (Walker, 1850), Fidicinoides
   spinicosta (Walker, 1850), Pacarina championi (Distant, 1881), Pacarina
   schumanni Distant, 1905, Majeorona aper (Walker, 1850), Majeorona
   truncata Goding, 1925, Quesada gigas (Olivier, 1790), Procollina n. sp.,
   Carineta cinara Distant, 1883, Carineta postica Walker, 1858, Carineta
   viridicata Distant, 1883, Herrera ancilla (Stal, 1864), Calyria telifera
   (Walker, 1858) and Conibosa occidentis (Walker, 1858) are provided. The
   new records increase the known cicada diversity 380% bringing the total
   number of cicada species reported in Nicaragua to 24 species in 16
   genera representing eight tribes and two subfamilies of the family
   Cicadidae.

   Second Avenue, Miami Shores, FL 33161-6695, USA, USA.

AN ZOOR14811074414
DT Article
TI Notes on some European Microgastrinae (Hymenoptera: Braconidae) in the
   National Museums of Scotland, with twenty species new to Britain, new
   host data, taxonomic changes and remarks, and descriptions of two new
   species of Microgaster Latreille.
AU Shaw, Mark R. (markshaw@xenarcha.com) 
SO Entomologist's Gazette
VL 63
IS 3
PS 173-201
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Based largely on the collection in the National Museums of Scotland, and
   concentrating on poorly understood taxa, 20 species of Microgastrinae
   are newly recorded from Britain, and host and/or other biological
   information is given for about 60 European species (in most cases the
   first host records; in some others refuting previous misconceptions).
   Among numerous taxonomic remarks on European species, three species are
   reinstated from synonymy (Dolichogenidea coniferae (Haliday, 1834),
   Dolichogenidea coniferoides (Papp, 1972), and Microgaster acilia Nixon,
   1968), and Choeras adjunctus (Nees, 1934) is proposed as a new
   combination. Two new species are described from reared British material:
   Microgaster arctostaphylica sp. nov. and Microgaster raschkiellae sp.
   nov.
C1 Shaw, Mark R.; Natl Museums Scotland, Chambers St, Edinburgh,
   Midlothian, EH1 1JF, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.

PT J
AN ZOOR14811074229
DT Article
TI Review of the Taxonomic status of Nyctelia multicristata Blanchard, 1846
   and description of Nyctelia confusa Zuniga-Reinoso sp. n. (Coleoptera:
   Tenebrionidae).
FT Revision del estado taxonomico de Nyctelia multicristata Blanchard, 1846
   y descripcion de Nyctelia confusa Zuniga-Reinoso n. sp. (Coleoptera:
   Tenebrionidae).
AU Zuniga-Reinoso, Alvaro (alzure@gmail.com) 
   Jerez, Viviane
SO Gayana
VL 76
IS 1
PS 38-45
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB There is confusion with the taxonomic validity of Nyctelia multicristata
   Blanchard in Hombron&Jaquinot (1846). This is because Kulzer (1963) in
   the review of the genus Nyctelia, redescribed the species N.
   multicristata and described a new species, N. fallax, based on unclear
   morphological traits which most are shared with N. multicristata.
   Morphological analysis revealed that specimens assigned to N. fallax
   must be synonymized with N. multicristata. Both the external morphology
   and genitalia reveals that the morphotype N. multicristata described by
   Kulzer corresponds to a new species.
C1 Zuniga-Reinoso, Alvaro; Concepcion Univ, Dept Zool, Concepcion, Chile,
   Chile.
EM alzure@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0717-652X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America
DE Nyctelia confusa [Chile /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Tenebrionoidea,
   Tenebrionidae
OR Nyctelia confusa - Zuniga-Reinoso 2012 (Tenebrionidae): [Sp nov, Chile,
   P. 41]. 
   Nyctelia multicristata - Blanchard in Hombron &  Jaquinot 1846

DT Article
TI Early Permian insects from Saar-Nahe Basin of Odernheim town site,
   Rheinland-Pfalz in Germany (Insecta, Grylloblattida, Blattinopseida).
AU Prokop, Jakub (jprokop@natur.cuni.cz) 
   Weiss, Klaus-Dieter
   Dechambre, Roger-Paul
   Nel, Andre
SO Geodiversitas
VL 34
IS 2
PS 271-281
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB New insect fossils from Early Permian lacustrine deposits of Odernheim
   town site (Saar-Nahe Basin, Rheinland-Pfalz, Germany) are attributed to
   Euryptilonidae (Grylloblattida) and Blattinopsidae (stem group of
   Dictyoptera). Oborella germanica n. sp. is based on fore- and hindwing
   venation pointing out difficulties of generic separation between Mania
   Kukalova, 1964 and Oborella Kukalova, 1964. In addition, as first
   revisors of the genus Blania, we consider it as a junior synonym of
   Oborella, because the holotype of the type species O. matura Kukalova,
   1964 is a better preserved specimen than that of Mania. We also describe
   another species, Oborella brauckmanni n. sp. Two Blattinopsidae are also
   described but not named for their incomplete state of preservation,
   although one is related to Glaphyrophlebia and could well correspond to
   a new species for its very long stem of posterior radius.

   Republic, Czech Republic.

DT Article
TI Metaconularia? pyramidata (Bronn, 1837): a scyphozoan from the
   Ordovician of Normandy, France, recorded for the first time as a
   reworked fossil in the Triassic of Devon, England.
AU Sendino, Consuelo (c.sendino-lara@nhm.ac.uk) 
   Taylor, Paul D.
   Van Iten, Heyo
SO Geodiversitas
VL 34
IS 2
PS 283-296
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A conulariid originally figured by Deslongchamps (1825) from the Gres de
   May (Caradoc) of Normandy as "Conulaire ondulee (var.)" is revised. It
   is one of the first conulariids to have been figured in the literature.
   This large species, preserved as sandstone steinkerns, has usually been
   referred to as Conularia pyramidata Hoeninghaus, 1830. However,
   Hoeninghaus' publication does not satisfy criteria of availability and
   the species should instead be attributed to Bronn, as Metaconularia?
   pyramidata (Bronn, 1837). A lectotype is chosen from the Bronn
   Collection. Metaconularia? pyramidata is recorded for the first time
   reworked into the Triassic Budleigh Salterton Pebble Beds Formation of
   Devon, England.
C1 Sendino, Consuelo; Nat Hist Museum, Dept Earth Sci, Cromwell Rd, London,
   SW7 5BD, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM c.sendino-lara@nhm.ac.uk

   Mesozoic

   systematics] [England / Devon, Budleigh Salterton / ] [Triassic /  / ].

DT Article
TI Revision of Mesozoic decapod crustaceans from Madagascar.
AU Charbonnier, Sylvain (scharbonnier@mnhn.fr) 
   Garassino, Alessandro
   Pasini, Giovanni
SO Geodiversitas
VL 34
IS 2
PS 313-357
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Decapod crustaceans from the Mesozoic of Madagascar have been studied by
   a number of authors during the last century. One of the largest sets of
   specimens was collected by the French General Maurice Collignon between
   1930 and 1950; this was subsequently studied by Secretan (1964) who
   described numerous species of macrurans, brachyurans, and axiideans.
   These crustaceans originate from the Upper Jurassic and the Upper
   Cretaceous of the Mahajanga Basin (NW Madagascar) and, especially, from
   the Morondava Basin (central-SW Madagascar). The purpose of the present
   study is twofold: to furnish an update of the stratigraphy and geology
   of the studied areas and, above all, to revise the Secretan's species,
   employing current systematic nomenclature, supplying for each detailed
   geographic and stratigraphic data since such were either cursory or
   incomplete in previous papers. The present revision considers 13 species
   recorded by Secretan as valid, namely: Enoploclytia collignoni Secretan,
   1964, Eryma granuliferum Secretan, 1964, Pustulina spinulata (Secretan,
   1964) (all Erymidae Van Straelen, 1925); Hoploparia collignoni (Van
   Straelen, 1949), H. c Secretan, 1964 (both Nephropidae Dana, 1852 sensu
   Tshudy&Babcock 1997); Ctenocheles madagascariensis Secretan, 1964
   (Ctenochelidae Manning&Felder, 1991); Schlueteria menabensis Secretan,
   1964 (Axiidae Huxley, 1879); Linuparus bererensis Secretan, 1964
   (Palinuridae Latreille, 1802); Dromiopsis pulchella Secretan, 1964
   (Dynomenidae Ortmann, 1892); Caloxanthus simplex (Secretan, 1964)
   (Etyidae Guinot&Tavares, 2001); "Xanthosia" robertsi Secretan, 1982
   (nomen novum pro Xanthosia elegans Secretan, 1964, non Roberts, 1962),
   Titanocarcinus mamillatus Secretan, 1964 (both Xanthoidea incertae
   sedis); and Secretanella arcuata (Secretan, 1964) (indeterminate
   family). The three species described by Secretan (1964) as belonging to
   the raninid genus Notopocorystes McCoy, 1849, N bituberculatus, N
   australis and N. denisae will be revised in a forthcoming paper. Our
   comparative studies have also revealed a number of synonymous taxa, as
   follows: Eryma granuliferum Secretan, 1964 (junior synonym: E.
   madagascariensis Secretan, 1964); Linuparus bererensis Secretan, 1964
   (junior synonym: L. bererensis multispinosus Secretan, 1964); Hoploparia
   collignoni (Van Straelen, 1949) (junior synonym: H. intermedia Secretan,
   1964 and H. sculpta Secretan, 1964); Schlueteria menabensis Secretan,
   1964 (junior synonym: S. tuberculosa Secretan, 1964). Lastly, we have
   doubts about the systematic validity of Enoploclytia armata Secretan,
   1964, Eryma australe (Secretan, 1964), and Coleia incerta Secretan,
   1964, because of the absence of main diagnostic features, useful for
   their systematic ascription.
C1 Charbonnier, Sylvain; Museum Natl Hist Nat, Dept Hist Terre, Case
   Postale 38,57 Rue Cuvier, Paris, F-75231, France, France.
EM scharbonnier@mnhn.fr
RI Charbonnier, Sylvain/AAU-9571-2020
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1280-9659

   Documentation; Publications; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa;

   Decapoda, Reptantia, Anomura, Astacura, Palinura

   Schlueteria menabensis - Secretan 1964 (Anomura): [Type locality,
   Designated, p. 348; Lectotype designated, P. 350; Syn nov, Schlueteria
   tuberculosa Secretan 1964, p. 346; Fossil]. 
   Enoploclytia? armata - Secretan 1964 (Astacura): [Taxonomic position, P.
   324; Fossil].

   madagascariensis Secretan 1964, p. 325; Fossil]. 
   Eryma? australe - (Secretan 1964) (Astacura): [Taxonomic position, P.
   327; Fossil]. 
   Hoploparia collignoni - (Van Straelen 1949) (Astacura): [Emended
   diagnosis, P. 333; Syn nov, Hoploparia intermedia Secretan 1964, p. 330;
   Syn nov, Hoploparia sculpta Secretan 1964, p. 330; Fossil]. 
   Coleia? incerta - Secretan 1964 (Palinura): [Taxonomic position, P. 338;
   Fossil]. 
   Linuparus bererensis - Secretan 1964 (Palinura): [Syn nov, Linuparus
   bererensis multispinosus Secretan 1964, p. 338].

AN ZOOR14811073847
DT Article
TI Fossil sponge gemmules, epibionts of Carpopenaeus garassinoi n. sp
   (Crustacea, Decapoda) from the Sahel Alma Lagerstatte (Late Cretaceous,
   Lebanon).
AU Petit, Gilles (gilles.petit@upmc.fr) 
   Charbonnier, Sylvain
SO Geodiversitas
VL 34
IS 2
PS 359-372
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The fossil crustaceans from the Sahel Alma Lagerstatte (Late Cretaceous,
   Lebanon), housed in the collection de Paleontologie of the Museum
   national d'Histoire naturelle, Paris, were examined in order to
   highlight the presence of epibionts. Marine sponge gemmules were
   recognized and are described for the first time on the rostrum of a new
   shrimp Carpopenaeus garassinoi Charbonnier n. sp. The exceptional
   conditions of fossilization in the Sahel Alma Lagerstatte also permitted
   the preservation of the gemmule germination and the first development
   stage of the young sponge. Tithe shrimp does not appear to benefit from
   the association, it ensures the transport and the colonization of new
   territories for the sponge. This association sponge/shrimp is not known
   either in the recent or in the past. It represents one of the first
   observations of a fossil shrimp epibiont. Carpopenaeus garassinoi
   Charbonnier n. sp. is the youngest record for the genus Carpopenaeus
   Glaessner, 1945 which was previously known from the Tithonian of Zandt
   (Germany) and from the Cenomanian of Lebanon (Hakel, Hadjoula
   Lagerstatten).
C1 Petit, Gilles; Univ Paris 06, Museum Natl Hist Nat, Case Postale 48,57
   Rue Cuvier, Paris, F-75231, France, France.
EM gilles.petit@upmc.fr
RI Charbonnier, Sylvain/AAU-9571-2020

SN 1280-9659

   Commensalism; Ecology; Fossilization; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Carpopenaeus [Phoresy / Porifera / Gemmules; new record] [State of
   preservation /  / Poriferan phoretic associates] [Lebanon / Sahel Alma /

   Carpopenaeus garassinoi [Lebanon /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ].

TI Oribatid mites (Acari: Oribatida) from the 'loreras' (Prunus lusitanicus
   L.) of Extremadura (Southwest Spain), and the description of a new
   species of Cosmochthonius Berlese, 1910 (Cosmochthoniidae).
FT Oribatidos (Acari, Oribatida) de las loreras (Prunus lusitanicus L.) de
   Extremadura (suroeste de Espana) y descripcion de una nueva especie de
   Cosmochthonius Berlese, 1910 (Cosmochthoniidae).
AU Subias, L.S. (subias@bio.ucm.es) 
   Shtanchaeva, U.
SO Graellsia
VL 68
IS 1
PS 7-16
PD enero-julio 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 1
AB L. S. Subias&U. Shtanchaeva. 2012. Oribatid mites (Acari: Oribatida)
   from the "loreras" (Prunus lusitanicus L.) of Extremadura (Southwest
   Spain), and the description of a new species of Cosmochthonius Berlese,
   1910 (Cosmochthoniidae). Graellsia, 68(1): 7-16 (in Spanish). The
   oribatid mites from the "loreras" (Prunus lusitanicus L.) are studied,
   and a checklist of the oribatids of Extremadura (southwest Spain) is
   given for the firs time. It contains 147 species, one of them new to
   science, Cosmochthonius lusitanicus n. sp., is described. The species
   Sellnickochthonius formosus (Cooreman, 1947) and Peloribates perezinigoi
   Shtanchaeva, Grikurova&Subias, 2011, and the subspecies Cerachipteria
   digita digita Grandjean, 1935, are recorded for the first time from
   Spain. This fauna is compared with that of the Iberian Peninsule, and an
   iberian species key of the genus Cosmochthonius Berlese, 1910 is given.

TI Moroccan Asidini VI. Description of three new species of the genus
   Alphasida Escalera, 1905 and one new subspecies of the genus Asida
   Latreille, 1802 (Coleoptera, Tenebrionidae).
FT Asidini marroquies VI. Descripcion de tres nuevas especies
   pertenecientes al genero Alphasida Escalera, 1905 y de una subespecie
   nueva del genero Asida Latreille, 1802 (Coleoptera, Tenebrionidae).
AU Perez-Vera, F. (fperezvera@yahoo.fr) 
   Avila, J.M.
SO Graellsia
VL 68
IS 1
PS 17-29
PD enero-julio 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four new taxa belonging to the Moroccan fauna are described in this
   paper, on the basis of specimens found in the collections of Coleoptera
   Tenebrionidae from the Museo Nacional de Ciencias Naturales (MNCN),
   Madrid and from the Museum National d'Histoire Naturelle (MNHN), Paris.
   The original labels of identification of the MNCN, in three cases
   represent a nomen in litteris, and one an erroneous identification. The
   specimens preserved in the MNHN were unidentified. Three of the new taxa
   are new species of the genus Alphasida Escalera, 1905, subgenus
   Glabrasida Escalera, 1910: Alphasida (Glabrasida) cobosi n. sp.,
   Alphasida (Glabrasida) dendriticosta n. sp. and Alphasida (Glabrasida)
   sefrouensis n. sp. The remaining taxon belongs to the genus Aside
   Latreille, 1802 and is related to Asida (Planasida) bereai Escalera,
   1907, but differs from the nominal form and from the other known
   subspecies in several characters; it is described as Aside (Planasida)
   bereai espagnoli n. subsp.

DT Article
TI Semperella megaloxea sp nov (Family: Pheronematidae): A new
   hexactinellid sponge from Andaman waters, India.
AU Vinod, K. (vinod_kavungal@yahoo.co.in) 
   George, Rani Mary
   Thomas, P.A.
   Manisseri, Mary K.
SO Indian Journal of Fisheries
VL 59
IS 1
PS 33-36
PD January-March 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 2
U2 5
AB The hexactinellid sponge described in this paper, Semperella megaloxea
   sp. nov. was collected from the eastern side of North Andaman waters off
   Diglipur at 13[degree] 06' N lat. and 93[degree] 11' E long, during one
   of the FORV Sagar Sampada expeditions. Critical examination of the
   specimen indicated that it belonged to the Class Hexactinellida,
   Sub-class Amphidiscophora and Order Amphidiscosida. Although diactin
   spicules are present, the presence of large number of pentactin spicules
   indicates that it belongs to the Family Pheronematidae. The columnar
   body with atrial surface divided into several areas separated by dermal
   areas indicates that the specimen belongs to the genus Semperella. The
   morphology of the whole sponge specimen, the presence of very long
   diactin spicules of oscular tuft and the pentactins with very long rays
   do not match well with any of the already described species of the genus
   Semperella Gray.
C1 Vinod, K.; Cent Marine Fisheries Res Inst, Mandapam Reg Ctr, Mandapam
   Camp, Tamil Nadu, 623520, India, India.
EM vinod_kavungal@yahoo.co.in

   species].

AN ZOOR14811074456
DT Article
TI Explosive radiation of the genus Schizopera on a small subterranean
   island in Western Australia (Copepoda : Harpacticoida): unravelling the
   cases of cryptic speciation, size differentiation and multiple
   invasions.
AU Karanovic, Tomislav (tomislav.karanovic@utas.edu.au) 
   Cooper, Steven J.B.
SO Invertebrate Systematics
VL 26
IS 2
PS 115-192
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 19
AB A previously unsurveyed calcrete aquifer in the Yilgarn region of
   Western Australia revealed an unprecedented diversity of copepods,
   representing 67% of that previously recorded in this whole region.
   Especially diverse was the genus Schizopera, with up to four
   morphospecies per bore and a significant size difference between them.
   Aims of this study were to: (1) survey the extent of this diversity
   using morphological and molecular tools; (2) derive a molecular
   phylogeny based on COI; and (3) investigate whether high diversity is a
   result of an explosive radiation, repeated colonisations, or both, size
   differentiation is a result of parallel evolution or different
   phylogeny, and whether Schizopera is a recent invasion in inland waters.
   More than 300 samples were analysed and the COI fragment successfully
   amplified by PCR from 43 specimens. Seven species and one subspecies are
   described as new, and three possible cryptic species were detected.
   Reconstructed phylogenies reveal that both explosive radiation and
   multiple colonisations are responsible for this richness, and that
   Schizopera is probably a recent invasion in these habitats. No evidence
   for parallel evolution was found, interspecific size differentiation
   being a result of different phylogeny. Sister species have parapatric
   distributions and show niche partitioning in the area of overlap.
C1 Karanovic, Tomislav; Hanyang Univ, Dept Life Sci, Seoul, 133791, South
   Korea, South Korea.
EM tomislav.karanovic@utas.edu.au
RI Cooper, Steven/I-6291-2012

   Marine &Freshwater Biology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1445-5226

   Genetics; Evolution; Habitat; Freshwater habitat; Zoogeography; Land

   Schizopera analspinulosa linel [Western Australia /  / New subspecies].

PT J
AN ZOOR14811074457
DT Article
TI A morphometric approach supporting genetic results in the taxonomy of
   the New Zealand limpets of the Cellana strigilis complex (Mollusca :
   Patellogastropoda : Nacellidae).
AU Reisser, Celine M.O. (celine.reisser@gmail.com) 
   Marshall, Bruce A.
   Gardner, Jonathan P.A.
SO Invertebrate Systematics
VL 26
IS 2
PS 193-203
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB The New Zealand Cellana strigilis complex has been traditionally divided
   into six subspecies. Recent molecular investigations, however, revealed
   that the complex comprises two clades. In this paper, an additional
   morphometric analysis on 160 shells from the two clades confirms the
   need for taxonomic reconsideration of the C. strigilis complex. Here,
   two species are recognised in the Cellana strigilis group, a western
   species, C. strigilis (Hombron&Jacquinot, 1841), from South, Stewart,
   Snares, Auckland and Campbell islands, with Patella redimiculum Reeve,
   1854 and C. strigilis flemingi Powell, 1955 as synonyms; and an eastern
   species, C. oliveri Powell, 1955, from Chatham, Bounty Islands and
   Antipodes Islands, with C. strigilis bollonsi Powell, 1955 and C.
   chathamensis of authors (not Pilsbry, 1891) as synonyms. Acmaea
   chathamensis Pilsbry, 1891 is based on mislocalised foreign shells,
   probably C. rota (Gmelin, 1791) from the Red Sea. A neotype is
   designated for P. strigilis Hombron&Jacquinot, 1841, lectotypes are
   designated for P. redimiculum Reeve, 1854 and A. chathamensis Pilsbry,
   1891, and a type locality is selected for P. redimiculum.
C1 Reisser, Celine M.O.; Univ Fribourg, Dept Biol, Fribourg, CH-1700,
   Switzerland, Switzerland.
EM celine.reisser@gmail.com
RI Gardner, Jonathan/M-3224-2016
OI Gardner, Jonathan/0000-0002-6943-2413; Reisser,
   Celine/0000-0002-1474-2967
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1445-5226
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type material; Synonymy; Biometrics; Skeletal
   and supporting structures; Shell; Shell morphology; Evolution; Marine
   zones; Pacific Ocean

   [Shell biometrics /  / ] [Phylogeny /  / ] [South Pacific / New Zealand
   / distribution]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Archaeogastropoda,
   Patelloidea

   P. 200].

   bollonsi Powell 1955, p. 200].

   redimiculum Reeve 1854, p. 197].

PT J
AN ZOOR14811075026
DT Article
TI Description of Eucephalobus esquiveli sp. n. and Acroukrainicus
   sagittiferus Holovachov, Bostrom &  Susulovsky, 2001 (Rhabditida:
   Cephalobidae) from Costa Rica.
AU Bostrom, S. (sven.bostrom@nrm.se) 
   Holovachov, O.
SO Journal of Nematode Morphology and Systematics
VL 15
IS 1
PS 13-19
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB One new species of Eucephalobus is described from studies by light and
   scanning electron microscope. Eucephalobus esquiveli sp. n. was
   collected from a Bromelia plant growing at San Luis de Monteverde, Costa
   Rica. It is characterized by a body length of 622-726 [mu]m in females,
   pharyngeal corpus 3-4 times isthmus length, spermatheca 35-74 [mu]m
   long, postvulval uterine sac 11-19 [mu]m long, and tail terminus bearing
   a harpoon-shaped, 2.5-3.5 [mu]m long, mucro. The new species resembles
   E. iaculocaudatus, but can be distinguished from it by several
   morphometric characters, and morphology of vagina and tail mucro.
   Specimens of Acroukrainicus collected from a grassland soil in Costa
   Rica are also described from observations by light and scanning electron
   microscope and found to agree well with the original description of A.
   sagittiferus from Ukraine, which is the only previous record of this
   species.
C1 Bostrom, S.; Swedish Museum Nat Hist, Dept Invertebrate Zool, Box 50007,
   Stockholm, SE-10405, Sweden, Sweden.
EM sven.bostrom@nrm.se
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Agriculture; Parasitology
SN 1139-5192

   diseases and disorders; Hosts; Habitat; Terrestrial habitat; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; Central America
DE Acroukrainicus sagittiferus [Grassland / Grassland soil / New record;
   systematics] [Soil habitat /  / ] [Costa Rica / La Amistad Pacifico
   Conservation Area / ]. 
   Eucephalobus esquiveli [Plant hosts / Bromelia / New parasite species]
   [Costa Rica /  / New species from plant host].

   (Nematoda): [Diagnostic characters, P. 18; Redescription, Adult &
   female, p. 16; New record]. 
   Eucephalobus esquiveli (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Costa Rica, Parasite of
   Bromelia (Plant), p. 14; Parasite].

   [Diagnostic characters, P. 18].

DT Article
TI Description of Chilodellus eremus gen.n., sp.n. and Stegelleta arenaria
   sp.n. (Rhabditida: Cephalobidae) from Kelso Dunes, Mojave National
   Preserve, California, USA.
AU Bostrom, S. (sven.bostrom@nrm.se) 
   Holovachov, O.
SO Journal of Nematode Morphology and Systematics
VL 15
IS 1
PS 21-31
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB A new genus and species, Chilodellus eremus gen. n., sp. n., and a new
   species of Stegelleta, S. arenaria sp. n., are described from the Kelso
   Dunes area, Mojave National Preserve, southern California. Chilodellus
   eremus gen. n., sp. n. differs from all other members of the
   Cephalobidae by the organization in the anterior end: three pairs of
   asymmetrical lips, each lip asymmetrically rectangular with acute
   extensions along the axils; U-shaped primary axils without guarding
   processes; secondary axils with two guarding processes;
   ventro-sublateral secondary axils asymmetrical; large oval amphids;
   three bifurcate labial probolae with tines located along the outer
   margins of the prongs; and by a poorly developed lateral field.
   Stegelleta arenaria sp. n. is characterized by a 489-640 [mu]m long body
   in females and 499-588 [mu]m in males; cuticle coarsely annulated and
   divided by regular longitudinal striations into 24-26 rows of blocks at
   midbody, each block with a central depression; lateral field with three
   incisures; three pairs of asymmetrical lips, pairs of lips separated by
   U-shaped primary axils without guarding processes, secondary axils
   demarcated by a shallow incisure, each lip asymmetrically rectangular
   with a smooth margin and one acute tine extending along the primary
   axil; three labial probolae, bifurcated at half of their length, prongs
   bent toward one another apically, "snake-tongue-shaped; pharyngeal
   corpus 3.2-5.0 times isthmus length; nerve ring and excretory pore at
   level of metacorpus to metacorpus-isthmus junction, deirids at level of
   isthmus; vulva sunken; spermatheca 19-29 [mu]m long; and postvulval
   uterine sac 19-45 [mu]m long.
C1 Bostrom, S.; Swedish Museum Nat Hist, Dept Invertebrate Zool, Box 50007,
   Stockholm, SE-10405, Sweden, Sweden.
EM sven.bostrom@nrm.se
SC Zoology
SN 1139-5192
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Nearctic
   region; North America; USA
DE Chilodellus eremus; Stegelleta arenaria [California /  / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Cephalobidae - Filipjev 1934 (Nematoda): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 22]. 
   Chilodellus (Nematoda): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Cephalobinae, Type
   species Chilodellus eremus, p. 22]. 
   Chilodellus eremus (Nematoda): [Sp nov, California, P. 23]. 
   Stegelleta - Thorne 1937 (Nematoda): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 29]. 
   Stegelleta arenaria (Nematoda): [Sp nov, California, P. 25].

DT Article
TI Description of Caveonchus ferrisae sp.n. (Dorylaimida: Leptonchidae)
   from northern Iran, with comments on the taxonomy of the genus.
AU Pedram, M.
   Pourjam, E.
   Pena-Santiago, R. (pourjame@modares.ac.ir) 
SO Journal of Nematode Morphology and Systematics
VL 15
IS 1
PS 33-40
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of leptonchid nematode, Caveonchus ferrisae sp. n.,
   collected in natural areas in northern Iran, is described and
   illustrated. It is characterized by its body 0.86-1.07 mm long, lip
   region cap-like but nearly continuous and 9-10 [mu]m wide, perioral area
   disc-like, odontostyle 10-11 [mu]m long, neck 161-189 [mu]m long,
   pharyngeal bulb 35-42 [mu]m long or one-fifth (19-21%) of total neck
   length, female genital system mono-opisthodelphic, anterior uterine sac
   40-95 [mu]m long, V = 41-46, tail short and rounded, spicules 30-37
   [mu]m long and three or four, widely spaced, ventromedian supplements.
   The taxonomy of the genus Caveonchus, very especially its separation
   from Basirotyleptus, is discussed in depth, and a key to species
   identification as well as a compendium of their morphometrics are
   provided.
C1 Pena-Santiago, R.; Univ Jaen, Dept Biol Anim Vegetal & Ecol, Campus Las
   Lagunillas S-N,Edificio B3, Jaen, 23071, Spain, Spain.
EM pourjame@modares.ac.ir

SN 1139-5192

   Basirotyleptus robustus - Siddiqi 1982 (Nematoda): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 34]. 
   Caveonchus - Siddiqi 1982 (Nematoda): [Diagnostic characters, P. 33;

AN ZOOR14811075029
DT Article
TI Some large-sized species of the genus Amphidelus Thorne, 1939 (Nematoda:
   Alaimida).
AU Andrassy, I. (istandrassy@gmail.com) 
SO Journal of Nematode Morphology and Systematics
VL 15
IS 1
PS 41-51
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three long-bodied (2.95-3.68 mm) and very slender (a = 60-95) Amphidelus
   species are described. Amphidelus longus sp. n. from Papua New Guinea is
   mainly characterized by an average body length 3.40 mm, thin cuticle,
   cup-shaped amphids, four or five male supplements and conical tail with
   arched and pointed tip. Amphidelus sp., also from Papua New Guinea, is
   on the average 3.46 mm long and closely related to the former species,
   but apparently differs from that by the elongate-caliciform amphids,
   open anal lips, six male supplements and conical, on its tip rounded
   tail. Amphidelus acutus sp. n. from Bolivia can be distinguished by its
   body length on the average 3.17 mm, comparatively thick cuticle,
   elongate amphids, four to six male supplements and conical tail with
   abruptly narrowed and sharply pointed tip. Besides, a female specimen of
   the largest species of the genus, Amphidelus boa, is also described.
C1 Andrassy, I.; Lorand Eotvos Univ, Dept Systemat Zool & Ecol, Pazmany
   Peter Setany 1-C, Budapest, H-1117, Hungary, Hungary.
EM istandrassy@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 1139-5192
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Biometrics; Land zones;
   Australasian region; Neotropical region; South America; Australasia
DE Amphidelus [Land zones /  / Distribution; systematics; large-bodied
   taxa]. 
   Amphidelus acutus [Bolivia /  / New species]. 
   Amphidelus boa [Size / Large body size / New record; systematics] [Papua
   New Guinea / Morobe, Mount Kumbak / distribution]. 
   Amphidelus longus [Papua New Guinea /  / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes

   New record].

AN ZOOR14811075030
DT Article
TI A subspecies of Bursaphelenchus corneolus Massey, 1966 (Nematoda:
   Aphelenchoididae) and synonymization of B. curvicaudatus Wang, Yu & 
   Lin, 2005 with B. corneolus.
AU Braasch, H. (h.braasch@t-online.de) 
   Gu, J.
   Wang, J.
   Wang, J.
   Burgermeister, W.
SO Journal of Nematode Morphology and Systematics
VL 15
IS 1
PS 53-67
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Three similar nematode populations of Bursaphelenchus are compared by
   morphology and molecular methods: B. corneolus, originally found
   associated with Dendroctonus adjunctus in ponderosa pine from New
   Mexico, USA; 'B. corneolus Taiwan', isolated from packaging wood from
   Taiwan; and B. curvicaudatus, from pine wood in Mexican cargo ships.
   Molecular phylogenetic trees based on SSU, ITS1/2, LSU D2/D3 and mtCOI
   sequences demonstrate the relationships between these isolates and to
   other Bursaphelenchus species. Sequence differences between species of
   the hofmanni group, between 'B. corneolus Taiwan' and B. curvicaudatus,
   and between different isolates within 'B. corneolus Taiwan' and B.
   curvicaudatus indicate that these two. taxonomic entities have the
   relation of subspecies to each other. Because of its higher
   morphological similarity to B. corneolus, particularly the long spicules
   and the strongly curved female tail, B. curvicaudatus is considered to
   be synonymous with the type population of B. corneolus, whereas the
   population provisionally named 'B. corneolus Taiwan' in several
   publications is considered to be a subspecies of B. corneolus and is
   here named Bursaphelenchus corneolus taiwanensis ssp. n. The nominate
   species is therefore B. corneolus corneolus. Bursaphelenchus corneolus
   taiwanensis ssp. n. is characterized by having three incisures in the
   lateral field; stylet with small basal swellings; females with a small
   vulval flap; post-uterine sac about 72% of vulva-anus distance; tail
   bent ventrad, hook-like and with finely rounded or pointed terminus;
   males having small mitten-shaped spicules, with high and sometimes
   square-shaped condylus, occasionally bent dorsad, rostrum triangular,
   distal end of spicules with a distinct cucullus; and seven caudal
   papillae. Bursaphelenchus corneolus taiwanensis ssp. n. is distinguished
   from B. corneolus corneolus (syn. B. curvicaudatus) by its somewhat
   smaller body, slightly different spicule shape, spicule size, and small
   differences in female tail shape.
C1 Braasch, H.; Kantstr 5, Potsdam, D-14471, Germany, Germany.
EM h.braasch@t-online.de
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology;
   Parasitology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology

   LSU D2/D3 sequence phylogeny / ] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Plant hosts / Pinus
   / ] [Stored product habitat / Packing wood / ] [Zhejiang / Ningbo Port /
   Morphology & systematics; imported from Taiwan] [Taiwan /  / ].

   [Stored product habitat / Packing wood / ] [Tianjin / Tianjin port /

DT Article
TI Hoverflies (Diptera, Syrphidae) from Kirgizia (regions Chuy, Naryn and
   Issyk-Kul) with description of two new species, Platycheirus nigritarsis
   sp n. and Platycheirus kirgizorum sp n.
AU Ssymank, Axel (Ssymanka@t-online.de) 
   Nielsen, Tore R.
SO Norwegian Journal of Entomology
VL 59
IS 1
PS 31-39
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A material of 109 hoverflies (Diptera, Syrphidae) from Kirgizia (regions
   Chuy, Naryn and Issyk-Kul) has been examined. Platycheirus nigritarsis
   sp. n. (of the ambiguus group) and Platycheirus kirgizorum sp. n. (of
   the manicatus subgroup) are described as new to science, and poorly
   known species like Cheilosia barkalovi Stahls, 1997, Chrysotoxum
   bajkalicum Violovitsh, 1973, Chrysotoxum tjanshanicum Peck, 1973 and
   Eristalis acutifacies Peck, 1971 are parts of the material.

DT Article
TI The influence of abiotic and biotic factors on the composition of
   Tetraodontiforms larvae (Teleostei) along the Brazilian Northeast
   Exclusive Economic Zone (1[degree]N - 14[degree]S).
AU Nogueira, Marcos Moura (mmouran@gmail.com) 
   Sampaio De Souza, Christiane
   Mafalda, Paulo, Jr
SO Pan-American Journal of Aquatic Sciences
VL 7
IS 1
PS 10-20
PD 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.panamjas.org/artigos.php?id_publi=191
AW http://www.panamjas.org/pdf_artigos/PANAMJAS_7(1)_10-20.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The aim of the present study was to verify the composition of the
   Tetraodontiforms larvae and to analyze the influence of abiotic factors
   (temperature and salinity) and biotic factors (phytoplanktonic and
   zooplanktonic biomass), on the spatial and temporal distribution of
   larvae. Ichthyoplankton was collected during Period: 1 (August [long
   dash] October 1995), 2 (January [long dash] April 1997), 3 (April [long
   dash] July 1998) and 4 (September [long dash] December 2000), realized
   in the Brazilian Northeast Exclusive Economic Zone (BNEEZ). We examined
   1230 Bongo-net (300 and 500 [mu]m) samples units that contained 51
   Tetraodontiforms larvae from six families: Balistidae (Balistes
   capriscus), Monacanthidae (Stephanolepis hispidus), Ostracidae
   (Lactophrys trigonus), Tetraodontidae (Sphoeroides sp.1 and Sphoeroides
   sp.2), Diodontidae (Diodon hystrix) and Molidae (Ranzania laevis).
   Sphoeroides sp.1 was the species highest relative abundance (36%), with
   higher value during the Period 3 (20%), while the Period 1 was recorded
   low relative abundance (2%). B capriscus was the second species with
   highest relative abundance (18%), with higher values during the period 2
   and 3. The results demonstrated that abiotic and biotic factors
   influence the distribution and abundance of Tetraodontifomes larvae in
   the BNEEZ leading each species to occur in a period and place more
   favourable to spawn.
C1 Nogueira, Marcos Moura; Universidade Federal da Bahia, UFBA,
   Departamento de Zoologia, Laboratorio de Plancton, Av. Adhemar de
   Barros, Campus Ondina CEP 40170-290, Salvador, Bahia, Brazil, Brazil.
EM mmouran@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Reproductive Biology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Marine
   &Freshwater Biology
SN 1809-9009
BD Reproduction; Reproductive behaviour; Ecology; Habitat; Abiotic factors;
   Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean
DE Tetraodontiformes [Breeding site / Spawning areas / larva; plankton]
   [Community structure /  / ] [Distribution within habitat / Spatial &
   temporal distribution / ] [Marine habitat /  / ] [Abiotic factors /  / ]
   [South Atlantic / Brazil / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii
OR Tetraodontiformes (Actinopterygii).

DT Article
TI On some species of Taeniotes Audinet-Serville, 1835 (Coleoptera:
   Cerambycidae: Lamiinae).
AU Martins, Ubirajara R.
   Santos-Silva, Antonio (toncriss@uol.com.br) 
SO Pan-Pacific Entomologist
VL 88
IS 1
PS 35-57
PD January 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Taeniotes farinosus (Linnaeus, 1758) is a species that has been confused
   with other species during the past two centuries. In this work we
   demonstrate that Taeniotes farinosus sensu auctorum is not the species
   described by Linnaeus and designate a lectotype to establish its
   identity. Taeniotes pulverulentus (Olivier, 1790), currently synonymous
   with T. farinosus, is revalidated. Taeniotes guttullaris Schwarzer, 1929
   and T parafarinosus Breuning, 1971 are junior synonyms of T.
   pulverulentus; Lamia subocellata Olivier, 1792 (= Taeniotes
   subocellatus) is a junior synonym of Cerambyx farinosus (= T.
   farinosus). Additionally we provide annotated bibliographic references
   to T. farinosus and T pulverulentus. Taeniotes monnei, a new species
   from Brazil and Argentina, is described and figured. Taeniotes peruanus
   Breuning 1971 is figured for the first time.
C1 Santos-Silva, Antonio; Univ Sao Paulo, Museu Zool, Caixa Postal 42494,
   Sao Paulo, BR-04218970 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM toncriss@uol.com.br
SC Zoology
SN 0031-0603
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Description;
   Synonymy; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Taeniotes monnei [Argentina /  / New species] [Brazil /  / ].

ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Cerambycidae

DT Article
TI The albibarbis-complex of Efferia Coquillett, 1910 from the Grand Canyon
   region, southwestern USA, with three new species and new distribution
   records (Diptera: Asilidae).
AU Scarbrough, Aubrey G. (saubrey05@gmail.com) 
   Stevens, Lawrence E.
   Nelson, C. Riley
SO Pan-Pacific Entomologist
VL 88
IS 1
PS 58-86
PD January 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Six species of the albibarbis complex of Efferia Coquillett are reported
   from the Grand Canyon ecoregion on the southern Colorado Plateau in
   northern Arizona. The terminalia of E. albibarbis (Macquart), E. bicolor
   (Bellardi) E. carbonaria sp. nov., E. fisheri sp. nov.. E. tapeats sp.
   nov., and E. zonata (Hine) are figured and compared with congeners.
   Efferia peralta Wilcox and E. Vertebrata (Bromley) are included as
   comparisons and possible members of the Grand Canyon faunas. The range
   of E. bicolor has been extended northward from central Arizona to within
   51.5 km of the south rim of the Grand Canyon and into Nye County,
   Nevada. Efferia fisheri is recorded along the southern edge of the
   plateau at Payson, AZ, 169 km south of the GCNP. Taxonomic and
   distribution notes are provided. Wilcox's key of this complex is revised
   to include all species described since his publication. Four of the six
   species overlap in low-elevation perennial stream riparian zones and in
   adjacent colluvial brecchia habitats in the Grand Canyon region. Efferia
   bicolor, E. fisheri, and E. zonata overlap at higher elevations.

   85721, USA, USA.

TI Nomenclatural history of Melanophila drummondi ab. nicolayi Obenberger,
   1944 (Coleoptera: Buprestidae), a change of authorship and synonymy
   under Phaenops drummondi (Kirby 1837), and a new distribution record and
   summary of larval hosts for the species.
AU MacRae, Ted C. (ted.c.macrae@monsanto.com) 
   Westcott, Richard L.
SO Pan-Pacific Entomologist
VL 88
IS 1
PS 87-91
PD January 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Melanophila drummondi ab. nicolayi Obenberger 1944 has been listed in
   some of the more recent literature as M. drummondi nicolayi Obenberger,
   thus creating problems with interpretation of its status as an
   unavailable name under Articles 13 and 45.6.2 of the ICZN (1999). This
   issue is discussed. Based on examination of a photograph of the type
   specimen, we consider the taxon unworthy of separation from Phaenops
   drummondi (Kirby 1837), which is compared to similar species occurring
   in its range. A new distribution record and summary of known larval
   hosts are provided for the species.

   63017, USA, USA.

DT Article
TI On the identity of Pontania dolichura (Thomson, 1871) and Pontania
   femoralis (Cameron, 1876) (Hymenoptera: Tenthredinidae: Nematinae).
AU Vikberg, Veli (veli.vikberg@aina.net) 
   Malinen, Pekka
SO Sahlbergia
VL 18
IS 1
PS 25-39
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The lectotype of Pontania dolichura (Thomson, 1871) represents the
   species which induces galls on Salix lapponum L. Its new synonym is
   Pontania lapponicola Kopelke, 1994, syn. nov. A lectotype is designated
   for Pontania femoralis (Cameron, 1876); according to the original
   description the larval food plant of the species is Salix phylicifolia
   L. Pontania robbinsi Benson, 1935 is an objective synonym of it. New
   adult characters are presented to separate the two species from each
   other. Pontania nigricantis Kopelke, 1986, based on the galls on S.
   myrsinifolia Salisb., is added to the fauna of Finland.
C1 Vikberg, Veli; Liinalammintie 11 as 6, 14200 Turenki, Finland, Finland.
EM veli.vikberg@aina.net
SC Zoology; Parasitology

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe

   /  / distribution] [Norway / South / ]. 
   Pontania nigricantis [Plant hosts / Salix myrsinifolia / New record]
   [Finland /  / ].

TI Two new species of the genus Leptogenys from Guangxi, China
   (Hymenoptera: Formicidae).
AU Zhou, Shanyi (syzhou5612@yahoo.com.cn) 
   Chen, Yuan
   Chen, Zhilin
   Zhou, Pining
   Ban, Daxiong
   Huang, Mingying
SO Sociobiology
VL 59
IS 3
PS 885-892
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB Two new species of the ant genus Leptogenys Roger, 1861 from China are
   described, i. e. L. laeviterga sp. nov. and L. rufida sp. nov.. L.
   laeviterga is close to L. strena Zhou, but mandibles without tooth;
   anterior margin of clypeus truncate and with a pair of denticles in the
   middle; meso-propodeal suture deeply depressed. L. rufida is close to L.
   confucii Forel, but dorsum of head in front of the eyes finely
   punctuate; anterior margin of clypeus rounded and with a pair of
   denticles in the middle; body brownish red. A key to all known species
   of the genus from China based on the worker caste is provided.

   Guilin 541004, China, China.

DT Article
TI Negative effects of Azteca ants on the distribution of the termite
   Neocapritermes braziliensis in Central Amazonia.
AU Pequeno, Pedro A.C. Lima (pacolipe@gmail.com) 
   Pantoja, Pauline O.
SO Sociobiology
VL 59
IS 3
PS 893-902
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 17
AB Termites play important roles in tropical ecosystem functioning, and
   their evolutionary success has been linked to their defense mechanisms.
   However, microhabitat overlap with potential aggressors may constrain
   their distribution and thus, their environmental impacts on an
   ecological timescale. We investigated a possible negative effect of
   abundant generalist ants (Azteca sp.) on the termite Neocapritermes
   braziliensis. Both taxa frequently build their nests attached to trees.
   We determined the densities of their active nests in 10 plots (250 x 10
   m) systematically distributed over 5 km2 in central Amazonia, Brazil,
   and recorded their co-occurrence in individual trees. Using generalized
   nonlinear modeling in a Bayesian framework, we found good support for a
   negative effect of Azteca's nest density on N braziliensis'. This effect
   conformed to a power law, and accounted for more than half of the
   variation in the termite's nest density (r2 = 0.56). Additionally, of
   all counted N braziliensis mounds, only 1.08 percent was attached to
   trees also hosting Azteca. Such patterns may have arisen due to N
   braziliensis' inability to establish new nests within Azteca
   territories, or predation by ants on established colonies of the
   termite. We suggest that even non-strictly termitophagous ant species
   may have important impacts on termite populations and, consequently, on
   their roles in nutrient cycling and ecosystem engineering.
C1 Pequeno, Pedro A.C. Lima; Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas da Amazonia
   (INPA), Programa de Pos-Graduacao em Ecologia, Av. Andre Araujo 2936,
   Petropolis, Caixa postal: 478, Manaus, AM, CEP: 69011-970, Brazil,
   Brazil.
EM pacolipe@gmail.com
SC Entomology; Zoology; Nutrition &Dietetics; Behavioral Sciences;
   Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Forestry
SN 0361-6525
BD Nutrition; Diet; Prey; Behaviour; Ecology; Population dynamics;
   Predators; Habitat; Terrestrial habitat; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Azteca [Insect prey / Neocapritermes braziliensis (Isoptera) / Negative
   effects] [Territoriality /  / ] [Population density / Nest density / ]
   [Forest and woodland / Lowland rainforest / ] [Brazil / Amazonas, Purus
   & Madeira rivers area / ]. 
   Neocapritermes braziliensis [Population density / Nest density /
   predation risk & other negative effects] [Insect predators / Azteca
   (Hymenoptera) / ] [Distribution within habitat /  / ] [Forest and
   woodland / Lowland rainforest / ] [Brazil / Amazonas, Purus & Madeira
   rivers area / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates

   Formicoidea, Formicidae, Isoptera

UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14811075424
